PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In view of the total rejection by conservationists of Mrs Kelly's version of what she said, will the Minister table the tape-recording and any other records of conversation of the meeting that the Minister for the Environment, Mrs Kelly, had with conservationists last week at which she described the Prime Minister's new federalism as `crass politics'?

—The short answer to Senator Baume's question is no. I do not believe it has ever been the case that Ministers, either in this Government or indeed in the one that preceded it, have been in the habit of tabling tape-recordings that may have been made at private meetings. The Prime Minister accepts Mrs Kelly's word and so do I.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In that case, I ask the Minister whether he has sought the approval of the other people who attended that meeting, particularly Mr Toyne and other conservationists, for the release of this tape as they have all, to my knowledge, advised the media and the coalition parties that they have no objection to the public release of that information.
—I certainly have not sought their approval. If Senator Baume is asking whether Mrs Kelly has, in view of what she said about not tabling the tape, she probably has not. I will certainly ask her.
—She's scared stiff.

—It is not a matter of being scared stiff, as one interjector said; it is a matter of principle as to which meetings are private and which are not. She is just abiding by that principle. Nevertheless, I will check it out with her.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to reports in this morning's media of the ACTU's congress decision yesterday to adopt a charter for jobs. In light of last week's easing of interest rates by a full one per cent, is there scope for the Government to consider the kinds of initiatives advocated by the ACTU to promote employment growth?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections. All interjections are disorderly, particularly when a senator is asking a question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston intruded with one of his sort of supplementary questions when Senator Crowley was asking that question. The suggestion, when Senator Crowley was talking about unemployment projections, was that the Budget is dead in the water. With respect to unemployment projections, the interjection could not have been more misplaced than others made on previous occasions. In answer to Senator Crowley's question, let me say first of all that the Government shares the ACTU's concern about unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: Unemployment in this country is too high as a result of the recession. Before the recession, economic policy and industry policy had created a climate in which 1.6 million jobs had been created in Australia. I make the point that even with the job losses which have been occasioned by the recession, there are still 1.3 million jobs more than there were when this Government came to office.

I note that the ACTU Secretary is reported as saying that the ACTU is not fundamentally at odds with the Federal Government on the issue of economic management. The objects pursued by the ACTU at its congress coincide precisely with the objects of the Government; that is, the return to steady and sustainable job growth underpinned by continued improvement in the competitiveness of Australian industry. I am quite willing to discuss any specific initiatives the ACTU wants to put forward in relation to problems which it has identified in its congress.

The best way to create employment is not through massive pump priming in order to create jobs. The best way of increasing employment is to remove the impediments to private sector investment in Australia, which is something about which the Government shares a common concern with the ACTU. However, it is not helpful to anybody who is unemployed or interested in investment in this country to provide magic wand solutions to some of these problems. The current magic wand being waved nervously by the Opposition, of course, is the consumption tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which you support!

—It is something which the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer refuse to spell out in any detail. Indeed, as Senator Boswell well knows, at the National Party Conference at the weekend the unhappy members of the conference were lead along to debate the consumption tax on the stated assumption that it would be less than 15 per cent. You can lead a horse to water, but you cannot make it drink at a 15 per cent consumption tax level-not in the National Party.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason this nervous magic wand is being waved around by the Opposition is its failure to work through the basic premises of a consumption tax and how to sell it. Senator Vanstone has published a document on how to sell a consumption tax. There is a picture of a tank on the front of the document. The caption under the caricature of the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, says `Dr Hewson is no wimp'. Dr Hewson has a soldier with a rifle standing beside him just to reassure him that he is no wimp.

Senator Vanstone goes on to say that the Liberal Party has to accept that popularity is not everything. I thought that would have been something that it would have accepted over the last decade. It is said by Senator Vanstone that lots of things are unpopular at first glance, but that does not mean we do not need them-for example, pain-killing injections, going to the dentist or having chemotherapy. These are the sorts of analogies which Senator Vanstone draws with the consumption tax proposed as a magic wand by the Opposition parties. The consumption tax is a magic wand.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Senator Crowley's question?

—I have already dealt with some of the most important parts of Senator Crowley's question in terms of the art form which one has to acquire in this job of answering a question. I will come back to other parts of Senator Crowley's question in a minute. I am just uttering a warning for those people-whether they be in the ACTU or in the Senate-who see the solution to the questions posed by both Senator Crowley and the Australian Council of Trade Unions in such glib terms and hook all of their belongings to this particular cart which Dr Hewson is trying to drive through.

ANSWER.PARA: If I can mix my metaphors for a minute, Senator Vanstone compared that cart with chemotherapy. The Opposition has no other proffered solution to the sorts of questions that are being raised by the ACTU. As I have said on previous occasions in the Senate, the solution to those questions really is in re-encouraging successful private sector investment in this country; not by waving magic wands or introducing a consumption tax as a panacea to all the problems which confront the Australian investment community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and, I think, representing the Treasurer on matters of Commonwealth-State relationships. I preface my question by referring the Minister to Mrs Kelly's part in the continuing campaign to undermine the Prime Minister by ridiculing new federalism as `crass politics'. Are there any moves within the Government to lessen Commonwealth control over environmental matters? Further, does the Minister believe that the present distribution of control over environmental matters between the Commonwealth and the States is appropriate and effective? If not, how should it be changed?
—First of all, I do not wish to add anything to what Mrs Kelly has said about that alleged discussion.
—Crass politics!

—Senator Boswell interjects to describe it as crass politics. He would know all about that; he has been involved in that for years. In answer to Senator Macdonald's substantive question, I do not regard the present arrangements between the Commonwealth and State governments in respect of a variety of functions as satisfactory. I would certainly include environmental management amongst those functions. Since there is a discussion taking place at the Premiers Conference on the appropriate division of responsibilities between the Commonwealth and State governments on this issue, I do not want to prejudge or prejudice any of those discussions.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If I understand Senator Button correctly, he said that he was not happy with the sharing of power on environmental matters. Does part of his concern arise out of the inability of the Federal Government to proceed towards a decision on the Tully-Millstream hydro-electric project extension because of the Queensland Government's stalling on the project? I use the word `stalling' because it was used by departmental officers this week in Senate Estimates committee meetings when they suggested that the Queensland Government--
—This is not an adjournment debate.

—If Senator Collins listens, he might understand what I am talking about. However, he will not understand those things. I wonder whether Senator Button could indicate if that is the sort of problem that he is concerned about, namely, the Queensland Government's stalling on these matters of environment. Is that the sort of problem that he is concerned about in the sharing of powers relating to the environment?
—I hardly think it is a supplementary question.

—In my original answer to the question asked by Senator Macdonald, I said that there were many matters in respect of which I thought Commonwealth-State functional arrangements were not as good as they ought to be. I said that the environment was amongst those matters. I am not familiar with the Tully-Millstream project, but it may well be that it falls into the category of an example. I will try to find out more details about that project. Because Senator Macdonald has had the advantage of questioning about this matter at a Senate Estimates committee, he may be much better informed than I am, and in that sense the question is not only not supplementary but also redundant.

—I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade whether it is true, as claimed in an article in today's Canberra Times, that Australia's flood relief to Cambodia, as announced last week, has dried up?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not true and that is yet another extremely misleading headline from the Canberra Times-something which has become endemic, I am afraid, with that paper. The article, if one reads what it actually says, makes clear that there are no references to any moves on Australia's part to cease assistance. In fact, it refers to funding problems for some UN agencies involved in the relief effort. Even here it is out of date. The UN in Bangkok has told us that it is making additional funds available to purchase relief supplies and has asked that the Australian Hercules stay on to fly more Bangkok-Phnom Penh-Bangkok shuttles.

ANSWER.PARA: The current scheduling is for two shuttles to be flown today-10 September-and two tomorrow. This would bring the total number to six. These shuttles have been absolutely crucial in bringing in urgently needed relief supplies to Cambodia. The main items involved have been sandbags for the construction of levies, medical supplies, blankets and mosquito nets. There is no doubt that, in sending the Hercules with a full relief cargo to Cambodia and then making it available to ferry in supplies from Bangkok, Australia has made a very significant contribution to the flood relief.

When I announced the relief flight last week, I did point out that an Australian disaster response expert would go into Cambodia on that flight. His brief is to monitor the Australian aid and to look into possibilities for additional assistance as well as the flight itself. We are presently awaiting his reporting before we make decisions on any such assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Firstly, does the Prime Minister stand by the Government's response to the Australian Conservation Foundation's 1990 election questionnaire, which pledged to assert greater Commonwealth power over the environment? Secondly, does the Prime Minister acknowledge that Discussion Draft Number 4 of the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment dated April 1991 in fact does the reverse, in ceding substantial Commonwealth control to the States? Thirdly, what justification does the Prime Minister offer for a process which, as this draft agreement indicates, relegates the Commonwealth to a role equivalent to the post-coup central government of the Soviet Union, unable to act without the approval of the States? Finally, will the Prime Minister accept that the new federalism process needs a total rethink, as indicated by the front page story in Saturday's Australian, in which the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, was quoted by several sources as describing the process as `crass politics' and in which the prevailing Cabinet sentiment was described as resignation rather than enthusiasm?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the questionnaire which Senator Coulter refers to, the answer to that part of the question is yes. But once again it is a question in respect of what aspects and in what manner Commonwealth power is exercised. In so far as the discussion paper of the intergovernmental agreement is concerned, that agreement is still being negotiated between the Commonwealth Government and the States. Whatever may or may not have been in a discussion paper is not relevant as it has already been superseded by discussions.

ANSWER.PARA: I regard the analogy with the Soviet Union in relation to our particular federalism problems as being based on a false premise and not relevant to the sorts of issues which Senator Coulter raised in his question.

In so far as the fourth part of the question is concerned, I have already declined to comment on an article in Saturday's Australian. However, let me say, as I have already said in an answer in the Senate earlier today, that I do not regard any-or very few-of the arrangements between the Commonwealth Government and the States as functioning perfectly. I never have. Indeed, those arrangements have never functioned as one would wish in a modern economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister indicate whether the Government is prepared to more widely interpret the trade and commerce powers, the corporation powers and the external affairs powers in their application to the environment or is the Government seeking essentially to ignore these powers which it already possesses and to give over the care and control of the environment to the States in all those areas?

—I have essentially answered that question when I referred to the negotiations which had taken place about the discussion paper, to which Senator Coulter referred in the first part of his question. I think the use of external affairs powers by the Commonwealth in order to establish a Commonwealth environmental policy is probably necessary if Commonwealth environmental policy is to have any effect, but the substance of that issue is still being negotiated in discussions with the States. When there is an outcome, the Government will advise the honourable senator.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it true that the amendments made to the Industrial Relations Act last year have made union amalgamations much speedier by allowing multiple union amalgamations to be progressed simultaneously? Has this boosted the Government's micro-economic reform agenda of achieving larger industry-based unions? Have some of the success stories been the formation of the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Workers Union with a membership of around 241,000; a hospitality union with approximately 250,000 members; the Finance Sector Union with 109,000 members; the Public Sector Union with 103,000; and a telecommunications union with 81,000 members? Does the Minister expect the union rationalisation process to accelerate in 1991-92 as unions take full advantage of the amendments to the Act? Does the Minister expect that the goal of approximately 20 major unions by the year 2000 will be achieved?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is making a farce of Question Time. It is absolutely a dorothy dixer. If the Minister wants to put down a statement, he should put down a statement after Question Time. It is ludicrous that the Opposition has its Question Time taken up by dorothy dixers that the Minister hands out to his back bench. The back bench ought to be absolutely ashamed to accept them. If Government members are not prepared to ask their Minister proper, seeking questions, they ought not to ask questions at all.

—Whether there are `Hear, hears' or not, the question is clearly in order. There was no point of order. Senator Walters, you know that it was not a point of order. That is not a form of conduct that the Chair should have to stand.
—The answer to those questions is yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, and I hope so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Why has the Government cut the Australian Sports Commission's request for $3m for the Australian Olympic team for Barcelona to $1.5m in a budget that actually increases the overall sports funding, particularly in politically oriented areas? What action does the Government intend to take now that the Sports Commission has rejected the Minister's request to make up this shortfall from its funding to other sports and has written asking the Government to review its decision? What are the so-called administration savings that the Minister has now told the media can be made to make up this shortfall in Olympic funding? Is this a recognition that there was at least $1.5m in fat in the sports budget?

—As I understand it, the original request for the $3m was from the Australian Olympic Committee and that was supported by the Sports Commission. I think that was the evidence the Estimates Committee received last night. The Sports Commission had written to the Minister indicating that it would find it very difficult to find the $1.5m from within its budget. My understanding is that since then the Minister has spoken to Mr Ferguson the Executive Director who, as Senator Campbell mentioned, has said that there are administrative savings which can be made by the Sports Commission. As to where they are, I certainly do not know but I am more than happy to inquire from the Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister seen the transcript of comments made by Senator Hill on a Radio Australia broadcast last week that the Government should be putting greater emphasis on influencing political change through its aid program, that the aid budget is too high and that it is not directed at alleviating poverty? Is the Government prepared to follow Senator Hill's advice on this issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the transcript of Senator Hill's comments, along with those of several other Opposition members, on this subject. I have to say that were we to follow the advice of Senator Hill and the Opposition, our aid program would be utterly without credibility in the region and in the wider international community. I say that for a number of reasons.

ANSWER.PARA: In the course of his contribution on International Report, Senator Hill made it very clear that the budget for aid under the Opposition-were it ever to get into government-would be dramatically cut. He said that he expected that there would be less cash and there would be considerable expenditure cuts. That followed a comment on ABC radio on 30 August by Mr Reith who said:
I'd cut back on overseas aid. I don't understand what it is that drives the Government's priorities to be spending among other things $20m in this budget on world environment programs . . .

In light of all the crocodile tears that have been shed in the past day or two by the Opposition about this Government's environment policies, and to have that sort of statement about $20m being utterly irrelevant as effective, legitimate Australian expenditure coming from the mouth of the Opposition's shadow Treasurer makes absolutely clear what is the real attitude of this Opposition on environmental matters and positions and the nakedness of its policy credibility when it comes to that particular issue. Mr Reith's inability to understand what we are spending money on in terms of regional and worldwide environmental aid programs is matched only by Senator Hill's inability to understand-as also demonstrated in this particular transcript-just what legitimate aid expenditure is about in other areas.

Senator Hill said that infrastructural projects in Indonesia, such as the building of roads and bridges, did not help the poor; were not, in effect, a legitimate part of an aid program. It is an extraordinary statement to make and demonstrates that Senator Hill simply does not begin to understand the utility, the necessity, of roads and bridges and other forms of communication in enabling poor people in rural communities to get their produce to markets and to make it possible for other projects to take place which involve employment and income generation. To be engaged in infrastructure projects of that particular kind is the most fundamental and fundamentally useful of all forms of development assistance. The long term contribution to the problem of poverty that growth generating projects of this kind make is absolutely essential to any country's aid program. For the Opposition to dismiss this kind of thing with cavalier disregard demonstrates both ignorance and culpable negligence in understanding what aid is all about.

I remember one further aspect of the transcript which was referred to by Senator Childs in which Senator Hill comments on the legitimacy of linkage between the aid program and influencing political change. Again, were this to be applied in the way in which Senator Hill seems to want, it would involve us in totally neglecting claims for humanitarian relief for assistance to poor people in a number of countries if he thought that some other larger political objective was to be served thereby. There can be occasions where that is legitimate, but it is only on the most careful case by case assessment that can ever be so. To apply it in the way in which Senator Hill seems to be adopting as a general rule, governing the operation of a country's aid program, again demonstrates manifest insensitivity to what the legitimate priorities of an aid program should be and whom our aid is trying to target and to help.

The contrast between that sort of attitude that has been demonstrated both on the quantity and quality of aid and the performance of this particular government is immense. We have created a situation this year where far from cutting back the dollars devoted to aid, we have increased the dollar sum by $53m, and that represents a one per cent increase, a bouncing back to 0.35 as the percentage of ODA to GNP.
Senator Alston interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —If we had followed the Opposition's prescriptions last year, the ODA and GNP--
—Order! Senator Alston, I will ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw.

—I am indebted to you, Mr President. If the Opposition had proceeded with its policy prescription at the time of last year's Budget to delete $100m from the aid program, we would be confronting a situation where, instead of aid representing 0.35 per cent of our GNP, it would be running at 0.30 per cent. I simply make the point that we are not going to accept the Opposition's advice or analysis of this country's needs or any other aspect of the aid program. To do so would be utterly destructive of the needs, the interests and the legitimate claims of many people in our region and utterly destructive of Australia's international credibility.

—I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade whether he agrees with the opinion of his aid officials that the Magarini land project has been a failure at a cost to the Australian taxpayers of $25m.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Magarini land project in Kenya is an example of an aid project which went spectacularly wrong. AIDAB is unequivocal in its acknowledgment of that. It has been unequivocal in the commitment it has given over the last few years to evaluating every aspect of that program, analysing why and how it went wrong and ensuring that it never goes wrong on that sort of scale or in that way in the future. Every country in the world that is a supplier of aid has had unhappy experiences of that kind, and Senator Hill is demonstrating his ignorance once again in shaking his head at a proposition of that kind.

ANSWER.PARA: Aid programs occasionally are overambitiously and overoptimistically planned; they are on occasions poorly planned, poorly executed and poorly implemented. The important thing is to understand that when things do go wrong, we learn from that experience and ensure that it never happens again. What characterises this Government, as compared with the Opposition, is that we do learn from experience. The Opposition, like the Bourbons, learns nothing and forgets nothing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support provide an update on the impressive progress in shipping reform?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting--

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the catcalls opposite, the only accurate statement that I am aware of being issued in 18 months by Mr John Sharp has been, through clenched teeth, a grudging acknowledgment that the Government's shipping reform program has been a success. Perhaps some of his colleagues should check with him.

ANSWER.PARA: The Shipping Industry Reform Authority, which is overseeing the implementation of this reform program, currently running well ahead of schedule, recently released its latest six-monthly report. I am pleased to advise that the report indicates that the program is proceeding to schedule and will be completed by 30 June next year.

The recrewing program for existing ships is well advanced. Four hundred and twenty-two officers and ratings were removed from vessels by the end of June this year. A further phase to remove 120 ratings was completed at the end of August this year. The progressive removal of electrician and radio officer jobs throughout the fleet is continuing as training is completed by remaining officers and new radio equipment is installed.

Recently, agreement was reached on the restructuring of the shipboard catering department. This will result in further reductions in crew sizes on Australian ships. These improvements-and this is something that the Opposition has difficulty with-have all been achieved in an atmosphere of unprecedented industrial harmony between employers and employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I wonder whether, as it is as clear for you and the rest of the chamber to see that this is a ministerial statement, which we had all heard was coming, you could ask the Minister to explain to us why he has elected to speak on a dorothy dixer rather than properly make a ministerial statement. Was he not permitted to do so?
—Order! There is no point of order. In fact, the Minister had not been replying for a very great deal of time at all.

—The principal problem that Senator `Marge Simpson' and her colleagues on the other side of the chamber have is that these advances-which have been achieved in an era of industrial harmony-have slashed dramatically the level of industrial disputation in this industry and have, at the same time, improved productivity. That is something that the Opposition consistently says cannot happen. I repeat that the Opposition has grudgingly acknowledged publicly the substantial process achieved in the shipping reform area. Of course, the Opposition will not be fully satisfied until our policy of protecting the Australian indigenous shipping industry on our coasts is destroyed. This is despite the fact that all major maritime nations in the world have a similar policy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition continues to parrot invalid comparisons between various coastal and international freight rates in Australia without any examination of why foreign ships may offer cheap rates at the sacrifice of ship safety. The problem of the safety and integrity of ships is a major international problem. Since January last year, 39 large bulk carriers have either had major structural failures or have been missing or lost-that is, sunk-at sea with significant loss of human life as well as potential danger to the environment. That is a problem which I seriously suggest-and I hope in a non-partisan manner-that the Opposition should look at in reviewing its current policy on abolishing cabotage in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. During Question Time last Thursday, with regard to Robe River, the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: Since 1989, in cases involving the Seamen's Union there have been some eight appeals by Robe River-
I emphasise `eight appeals by Robe River'-
to the Industrial Relations Commission's Full Bench and two appeals to the High Court.
The Minister then went on to say:
In essence, the outcome of those appeals has been for the Seamen's Union to be upheld in all cases.

I ask the Minister: is it not a fact that two of the appeals were taken by the union, that several were won by the company and that the two High Court appeals are yet to be decided? If this is the case, why did the Minister mislead the Senate?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I did not mislead the Senate. If Senator Crane wishes to read the answer in its complete form, he will see that there has been no misleading of the Senate.

—Can the Minister for Industrial Relations advise the Senate whether the Government is confident that the moderate and economically responsible aggregate wage outcomes that have been evident under the accord are likely to continue as the wages system moves to a more decentralised basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are confident that in decentralising the wage fixing system, as accord mark VI contemplates, we will be able to manage the transference to a more decentralised focus without there being any massive blow-out in wage outcomes for this country. The basis for our confidence is that, if one goes back over the past seven years of the Hawke Government, we find that in five of those seven years the aggregate wage outcome has achieved the Budget forecast. Indeed, in three of those five years, the aggregate wage outcome significantly undershot the Budget forecast. In the two years that the aggregate wage outcome exceeded the forecast-in 1986-1987 and 1988-1989-there was a general level of economic activity much higher than forecast in the Budget at the time.

ANSWER.PARA: If I were to provide a cumulative total of the forecast aggregate wage outcomes for the seven Budgets of the Hawke years, the figure would be 56.5 per cent. If I were to compare that to the outcome, the figure would be 57.9 per cent. In other words, the forecast versus the outcome produces a difference of 1.5 per cent over seven years-an extraordinary achievement by this Government in terms of aggregate wage results. If we were to compare that with the record of the Fraser Government, we would find that in the seven years of the Fraser Government the forecast cumulative total was 106.9. The outcome is 113.7, which is a difference of around 7 per cent. That is quite an excessively high difference between forecast and outcome.

If one looks at those figures, one sees that in the seven years of the Hawke Government the outcome was 57.9 per cent in wages growth compared with the wages growth in the Fraser years of 113.7 per cent, or almost double that of the seven years of the Hawke Government. In other words, not only is this Government better able more accurately to predict the wages outcome, but as well the outcome is a much more moderate level than the excessive levels of the comparative period of years for the Fraser Government.

To complete the picture, it should also be said that during the period of the Hawke Government the economy has been growing at a much stronger rate than it did during the period of the Fraser Government. The average annual rate of GDP growth under our Government was 3.6 per cent per annum, whereas the average under Fraser was 2.1 per cent. So in a more strongly growing economy the wages outcomes were more moderate and the wages targets were met. On that basis we believe that the accord has demonstrated that it has served this community extraordinarily well as an economic tool on wages policy and that the ability to deliver those results seven years in succession causes us to be confident that, now we move to the more decentralised focus on wage fixing, the result can still be the same-our forecast will be met.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Button, as the Minister responsible for Australian industry, technology and commerce. What steps did the Minister take to maximise Australian content when the Civil Aviation Authority stupidly and foolishly restricted overseas tenders to only six companies when it called tenders for a new air traffic control system which, by its own admission, will cost $300m?

—I will get Senator MacGibbon a list of the various steps that I took on this matter. They were numerous. I had a number of meetings with the Australian industry. I encouraged the Australian industry to try to form a lead consortium to tender for this contract-unsuccessfully, in the time made available by the Civil Aviation Authority. I have had a number of discussions with Minister Collins and other Ministers about the matter. Indeed, my most recent advice is that there have been further meetings between the CAA and my Department. Although the board of the CAA took a decision which I personally regard as reprehensible, it is now making efforts to ensure a greater level of Australian content in respect of this contract. Indeed, a number of the participants in the major consortia which are tending for the contract have Australian subcontractors for software and other systems.

—I ask a supplementary question of the Minister. Is it not a fact that Australian companies wished to tender but that they were specifically forbidden from tendering by the restriction to overseas companies by the CAA? Finally, is it not Government policy to promote and support Australian industry participation?

—The answer to the second part of the question is yes. The answer to the first part is that the CAA, in what I would describe as a degree of ignorance, proceeded on the assumption that it could write specifications that would exclude an Australian tenderer. That was the course which a moment ago I described as reprehensible in my view.

—My question, which is also directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, refers to the proposed Cape York spaceport. I refer the Minister to reports of the second consecutive failure within a one-year period of the Soviet Zenit rocket. As the Minister would be aware, much of the argument about the economic viability of the spaceport has centred on the lower cost of these Russian launch vehicles. I ask the Minister: first, does he agree with the comments of Dr Bruce Middleton of the Australian Space Office that `The failure is not a major setback, but a disappointment'. Secondly, will not this technology, which uses large launchers and large payloads, be replaced in the very near future by a technology which produces smaller, disposable or even renewable satellites which require only small launch vehicles? Thirdly, with that in mind, would it not be wiser for the Government to be investing in Australian designed scram jet vehicles--
—A strange question for a Queensland senator.
—Developed in Queensland, Senator Macdonald, which, subject to the next stage of research and development, could be launched from Woomera?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question began by soliciting my comments on the spaceport proposal which, of course, is a Queensland proposal. It is quite distinct from any proposals which are currently being discussed in respect of the Woomera rocket range. I must say that at the start of Question Time Senator Kernot gave me an illegible photostat which depicts a Zenit rocket. I do not know what that means. ANSWER.PARA: These schemes, to which many nations subscribe, are in a sense arbitrary in their application. The Government considers that our present system, which provides for universal product coverage, no automatic country or product exclusion provisions and a uniform preference margin that is limited to five percentage points, represents a balanced package that accommodates the concerns of local industry and developing countries.

The fact that imports of pineapple products from the Philippines have increased to around 20 per cent of the local market does not justify singling out the local industry for increased import protection. I think some of the problems of the industry in Queensland are associated with lack of investment compared with the sort of investment levels which have taken place in countries such as the Philippines, largely at the instigation, as I think Senator Boswell's question points out, of United States companies.

The Government regards as extremely doubtful whether the removal of the preference margin would have any positive impact for the industry at all. Experience is that increased border protection measures will do nothing to ensure the long term viability of industry in general. The pineapple sector is unlikely to be an exception to that fact.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.

Engagement of Ministerial Consultants under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act, 1984 (MPO(S) Act)
The MOP(S) Act provides for Ministers to be able to appoint consultants, subject to the approval of the Prime Minister.
As a matter of Government policy only Cabinet Ministers are entitled to engage consultants. Non-Cabinet Ministers have no automatic entitlement.

The appointment process requires that a Minister write to the Prime Minister seeking approval to engage a particular consultant, setting out the proposed tasks to be performed, the consultant's background and experience, the Minister's view (if any) as to remuneration, and whether the consultant will be engaged full time or part time.

A copy of this submission is sent to the Secretary of the Department of Industrial Relations, who is responsible for determining the remuneration and other terms and conditions of service of the consultancy
- this responsibility was formerly vested in the Public Service Board and was delegated to the Secretary in 1987 on the abolition of the Board.

The Secretary decides the remuneration and terms and conditions taking into account the consultant's background, experience and previous remuneration, the proposed tasks, and the remuneration paid to consultants undertaking similar functions, and any other relevant factors.
A draft determination setting out the proposed remuneration and terms and conditions is sent to the proposing Minister.

The Merit Panel, which currently consists of Deputy Secretaries from the Departments of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Administrative Services and a nominee of the Minister for Finance, assesses the suitability of the consultant to the proposed task.
The matter is then considered by Cabinet.
If the consultancy is approved a final determination is issued by the Secretary of the Department of Industrial Relations.
The Department of Administrative Services administers the contract.
Early Termination Benefits
Where Ministerial Consultants are engaged on a contract of employment, the contract generally provides for a fixed term of employment, not exceeding three years.
The termination benefit is two months salary for each six months or part thereof of service forgone, with a minimum payment of four months and a maximum payment of twelve months salary
- where the Minister ceases to be a Minister as a result of an election, one month's salary is paid.
Dr Edwards' termination benefit was calculated on this basis.
Lesser benefits are paid where the contract is for a period of twelve months or less.

These arrangements are consistent with the early termination for benefits for fixed term appointees to the Senior Executive Service of the Australian Public Service whose appointments are terminated prematurely on other than health, unsatisfactory service or disciplinary grounds
- compensation where the appointment is terminated before completion of the turn for which he or she was appointed is based on that part of the term forgone.

Termination benefits for fixed term SES are equivalent to four months salary for each year of service forgone (for periods less than a year the amount is based on complete months forgone) with a minimum payment of four months and a maximum payment of twelve months salary.

The Remuneration Tribunal, in its 1985 report on its inquiry into a range of matters, including compensation for loss of office, recommended that compensation be provided for full-time public office holders
- with compensation to be calculated on the same basis as for Secretaries of Departments and members of the Senior Executive Service employed on a fixed-term basis.

Employment, Education and Training
(Question without Notice)
Senator Archer asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, a question and supplementary question without notice, on 9 September 1991:

Can the Minister explain why firms which employ staff on commission are not permitted to claim expenditure for the time spent by such staff attending eligible training programs even though, when calculating the training liability of the business, commission payments made to the same staff are deemed to be part of that firm's payroll?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bolkus

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

INTERJECT.PARA: Similar questions have been addressed in correspondence and discussions with the Real Estate Institute of Australia, involving my office and officials of my Department and the Australian Taxation Office. Commission payments to staff are not ``directly attributable'' to training, as required under s.25(1) of the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990. Unlike salary or wages paid to employees during their period of training, commission payments are only incurred during periods of work (eg sales activities) and are not a cost to the employer while the employee is in training.

On the other hand, commission must be counted in the employer's payroll, for purposes of determining the training obligation of the employer, as required under the definition of ``salary or wages'' in s.4 of the legislation. It is wholly reasonable to include commission in payroll as this is an alternative to other forms of remuneration (such as wages). It would be inequitable to employers in other industries if employers in commission-based industries had a much reduced or no obligation to train because commissions were excluded from payroll.

Salaries and commissions are both forms of remuneration to employees and therefore form part of payroll for purposes of the Training Guarantee. The essential difference is that salaries are paid to employees during their training and work periods whereas commission is only payable when the employees are in a working situation.

It is far more important when we have Mrs Kelly defaming the good name of all those conservation leaders who have gone on record as saying that Mrs Kelly did describe Mr Hawke's new federalism as crass politics. I do not believe that it is proper for this chamber or for the Parliament as a whole to allow the clear implications of Mrs Kelly's statements to remain unchallenged. In particular, I think it is important that the people of Australia should not be left in a situation where the integrity of those conservation leaders is left in doubt because of Mrs Kelly's assertions or, indeed, the assertions of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the other chamber just a little while ago in Question Time when he claimed that a member of his staff had heard the tape and, as a result, the Prime Minister had no problems with this matter. If that is so, there is no problem here because there is nothing to hide.

The only reason for keeping this tape private is if there is something to hide. What is there to hide? Mrs Kelly said that she cannot reveal this because it is a private conversation. She has repeated that several times. How curious that it is a private conversation. All the participants in that conversation are happy for it to be revealed, except one person-Mrs Kelly. She is the only person who is being charged effectively with having misled the House of Representatives, with having misled the people of Australia and, in fact, with having impugned the good name and the integrity of those conservationists who, with clear recollection, have said exactly what Mrs Kelly told that meeting. The only private element of that meeting is that Mrs Kelly wants it to stay private. She does not want that tape to be released, revealing to us exactly what she did say and whether the conservationists were totally right and she was totally wrong.

In the other chamber just now, my colleague Mr Chaney said that various conservationists-for example, Mr Toyne-have said that they have absolutely no difficulties about the material being disclosed. There are no difficulties in truth and honesty in revealing what is on the tape and in it being tabled here. There are difficulties in Mrs Kelly having to stand by her statement that she did not claim that Mr Hawke's new federalism was crass politics. The only conclusion, unless this tape is tabled, is that Mrs Kelly is the one who is misleading the Australian people and the conservationists are telling the truth. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That there be laid on the table, on or before 11 September 1991, the tape recording of the discussions held on or about 4 September 1991 between the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the Honourable R. J. Kelly, MP, and representatives of conservationist groups.

Senator Robert Ray asked that this debate be factual and straightforward. What a shame that Senator Ray when making that request seemed so determined to avoid the substance of the merits of this matter. The merits are very straightforward and simple. Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, in this particular case telling the truth or not, and is she impugning the integrity of conservationist leaders who have a totally different view and a totally different memory of what went on at that meeting on or about 4 September 1991, at which she described the new federalism of Mr Hawke as `crass politics?'.

All we have heard from the Government so far in the preliminary debate about whether we should have this debate was Senator Ray's suggestion that the coalition was on the wrong track and that I was telling what he said were `lies'-a word he had to withdraw. He said that I had claimed that Mr Hawke's staffer had heard a tape. Mea maxima culpa: he did not hear the tape; he read a transcript of the tape. Presumably, unless the transcript of the tape was doctored, he was as good as hearing the tape and he was aware of the contents of the tape. That is the matter of substance that this Government does not want to approach. It does not want to talk about the serious issues in this matter. The substance is that Mr Hawke's staffer saw a transcript.

I am suddenly alerted; I am cautious following Senator Ray's comments. If Mr Hawke's staffer did not actually hear the tape, will this be Mr Hawke's excuse when the transcript reveals, if it ever does come out, that the conservationists were right and Mrs Kelly was misleading the people of Australia and the Parliament? Will this be Mr Hawke's excuse for not taking action? Will he now say, `The transcript was doctored'? It seems to be the significance of Senator Ray's most curious intervention that there is some significant difference; a difference in substance between the tape-recording we have asked to be tabled and the transcript that Mr Hawke's staffer saw.

I must admit that I had not recognised that there was such a risk. I did not think that a Minister of the Crown would provide the Prime Minister with a doctored transcript, but obviously Senator Ray thinks it is a very real possibility. Senator Ray is, after all, Mr Hawke's campaign manager. At least he is one of the two of them. I believe that the other, Senator Bolkus, is fairly wobbly at the moment. Senator Ray is one of the two campaign managers for Mr Hawke's keeping the prime ministership and-surprise, surprise!-Mrs Kelly is in the other camp, the Keating camp.

Maybe there is a real reason for Senator Ray to express those concerns that the transcript was doctored and maybe that is why he made such a fuss about it. But this is a far more serious matter than just one of a tired, discredited ministry doctoring a transcript of what was supposed to have been said and giving it to the Prime Minister. It is far more serious than that. This is an issue which goes to the integrity of a Minister and the implications of her assertions about the integrity of the leaders of the conservation movement, who have clearly and uncomplicatedly said what was said and have confirmed repeatedly the comments that have been widely reported about Mrs Kelly saying that the whole process of the new federalism was crass politics.

This issue is central because what Mrs Kelly was saying-and I believe it will be supported by the tape when it is tabled-was that she is sabotaging the whole basis of the Government's policy in this area. She may well have a great desire to sabotage the Government's policy in this area. After all, she has a great desire to sabotage the Government-or at least the Government of this Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is backing Keating, isn't she?

—As my Leader says, she is backing Mr Keating. So there would be nothing strange, unusual or untoward about Mrs Kelly using this opportunity, in what she now describes as a private meeting, to undermine the Prime Minister or to try to repair some fences with the environmental movement. No doubt this is what it is all about. She was trying to have two bob each way: she was telling one story to the environmental movement and another to her Government. She was behaving in an inappropriate and unacceptable way for a Minister or, in fact, for any member of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: What intrigues me is that here is a Minister, whose statements are totally challenged and who is in effect facing a charge of falsehood, being defended by Senator Robert Ray's mock outrage at the fact that I had said one of Mr Hawke's staff had heard a copy of the tape rather than seen a copy of the transcript. If that is the best the Government can do-I look forward to hearing what Senator Richardson has to say-and if it cannot cope with the substance of this matter, it is even more bankrupt than it has made Australia. This is a disgraceful situation.

Let us deal with the matter of whether this was a private meeting and therefore should not be revealed. Not one member of the conservation movement who attended that meeting has expressed the view that this matter should not be made public. As the Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation told my colleague Mr Chaney, `I have absolutely no difficulties about the material being disclosed'. The coordinator of the West Australian Conservation Council, Ms Rachel Siewert, is reported in this morning's Australian as having said that:

. . . she would have regarded the meeting as private, but Mrs Kelly had ``put it up for grabs'' when she said on Thursday that the conservationists had raised none of their public grievances at the meeting, a statement Ms Siewert said was not true.

That is charge No. 2 of untruth against Mrs Kelly. Is it possible that all the conservationists are totally wrong in their recollections and that the only person with an accurate memory is Mrs Kelly? Of course there is the tape recording, but we cannot hear it because we are not allowed to hear it. The Minister in this chamber, Senator Richardson, said, `No, we will not table it'. Mrs Kelly has said today in the other place that no, she will not table it. We have to believe Mrs Kelly as against the combined leadership of the conservation movement-or a large proportion of it.
The coordinator of the Conservation Council of the South-East Region and Canberra, Mr Rodney Falconer, said yesterday:
. . . when referring to new federalism, Mrs Kelly said it was a piece of crass politics.
She did not point to any individual or group when she used the term . . . she definitely used it to describe what was going on.

That is in total conflict with the statement by Mrs Kelly. When Mr Hawke was asked what he was going to do about this, he said that he had more important things to do than listen to the tape. He had more important things to do than to find out the facts about the extent to which one of his senior Ministers has either misled him or misled the conservation movement.

As I say, this is a very central issue. I believe that what Mrs Kelly is trying to do-that is, sabotage the Government's policy-is something that maybe the conservation movement would welcome. But she has done it by trying to sabotage the integrity of the leaders of the conservation movement. As long as that tape remains not tabled, their word is in doubt in the minds of Australians because Mrs Kelly is in effect saying that they are not telling the truth and she is.

On those grounds, I believe that there is an unassailable case for this motion to be passed. A failure to pass this motion means that we are condemning those conservation leaders as people whose word is not to be trusted. I do not believe that that is an acceptable position. I believe it proper that Mrs Kelly should resolve this matter by ensuring that the Government makes the tape available to be tabled in this Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this motion because I am concerned that the whole system of the Government's decision making process is grinding to a halt. This Government is incapable of making a decision of any significance because it is too tied up in the stupid fight between Mr Keating and the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, on who wants to be leader of the Australian Labor Party and the Government. Every aspect of government these days is determined by the question of who wants to be and who has the numbers to be the leader of the ALP.

SPEECH.PARA: There are real problems with the environment and unemployment. Almost one million Australians are out of work. What does this Government do about those matters? It fights about who should be leader. Mrs Kelly deliberately set about to promote her candidate, Mr Keating, by destabilising Mr Hawke. That is what this is all about. She said these things, she accused the Prime Minister's new federalism of being crass politics, because she knew that that would create destabilisation in the Labor Party and in the conservation movement, most members of which are also members of the Labor Party. She deliberately set about to create this confusion and instability in the Government.

Mrs Kelly does not give a damn about the environment. She is more concerned in holding her position of power as Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. She knows, quite rightly, that as long as Mr Hawke stays as Leader of the Labor Party she has no chance of being the Minister for the Environment after the next election because she will be on the back bench-that is, if she is fortunate enough to retain her seat. Mrs Kelly knows, as does Senator Richardson, that as long as Mr Hawke is leader they have no chance of retaining power and of being in government. That is why they have to get rid of Hawke.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! `Mr Hawke'.

—Mr Hawke. They do not care how they do it or who they hurt in getting to that conclusion. They are determined, in whatever way possible, to destabilise Mr Hawke. That is okay-I do not particularly care about that-but it is no good for Australia. That is what this debate is all about: it is a silly little matter about what was said. It could be very easily cleared up but, instead, we are left with three or four days of newspaper speculation and time being taken up in the Parliament on who is telling the truth. Is Mrs Kelly telling the truth or are the conservation leaders telling the truth? Which one is it? We have had three days of debate and uncertainty and government decision making is just falling down while members of the Labor Party indulge themselves in these family wars on who should be leader.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of making the hard decisions on the environment, we have this petty debate about what Mrs Kelly said. Mrs Kelly should be more concerned about what is happening in the environment. For example, she should be out there making the decisions on Tully-Millstream. She should be finding out why the Queensland Government is stalling on that issue and why it will not give the Federal Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories the information it needs to come to a conclusion on the matter.

Is Mrs Kelly concerned about that? Of course she is not. She is more concerned about retaining her job. To do that she has to get rid of Mr Hawke. The whole Government should be doing something about the one million Australians who are unemployed. But are Ministers interested in doing that? They are more interested in trying to get rid of Mr Hawke so that they have some chance of maintaining their position in the Government. They know that as long as Mr Hawke stays they have no chance of getting back. The Government is breaking up over this continued leadership destabilisation, this continued leadership crisis, and Mrs Kelly is determined to stir it up.

If we were genuine about this-and this is what the motion comes down to-there is a very easy way to get rid of the question and to stop all the foolishness and pettiness that is going around in the Labor Party. We need to know exactly what is on the tape. That is a very simple answer. It does not require any great intelligence to reach that conclusion-even members of the Labor Party could think of that. All that the Labor Party has to do is show what is on the tape. All the indecision and controversy will then go away and the Government will be able to get on with trying to run the country and trying to do something with the one million who are unemployed.

Will Mrs Kelly produce the tape? Will she let us all hear it? If she did, the controversy and indecision would be over in a flash. We would all be able to hear it; we would all know what was on it. We would be able to find out what she said and what she did not say. We would know whether she is telling the truth or whether the conservation people are telling the truth. It is very easy to have such an outcome-all she has to do is table the tape.

Why will Mrs Kelly not table the tape? The answer, the conclusion, to this problem seems to be very simple. Mrs Kelly knows that if she does not table the tape the matter will continue to grab headlines and continue to destabilise Mr Hawke. In that way, she has more chance of getting her favoured candidate, Mr Keating, elected as leader of the failing Labor Party. That is what it is all about. Obviously, Mrs Kelly is not prepared to put aside the petty politics and allow the tape to be tabled so that we can all hear and know what it is about and get on with the job that we are supposed to be doing. That is why I urge that the Senate pass this motion. Once we know what is on the tape we will be able to get on with the job that needs to be done here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion strikes at the very heart of the credibility of the Government. As has already been said, on the one hand we have the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) saying that she said one thing and, on the other hand, we have the conservationists saying that she said that Mr Hawke's new federalism policy was `crass politics'. The Minister says that she was referring to the States.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke must come out and prove once and for all who is telling the truth. Otherwise the conservationists will be left with a cloud hanging over their heads, because the Minister has virtually said that they are lying. We cannot allow that situation to continue. I am not accusing the Minister of lying. She has the opportunity to prove that she was telling the truth. Indeed, she has the opportunity to tell the people of Australia that she was telling the truth. The conservationists also have the right to tell the people of Australia that they were telling the truth.

As my colleague Senator Macdonald has already said, this seems to be such a small and paltry matter. But the credibility of a Minister is at stake. The fact that she has been accused of misleading the House is a very important issue; it is something that must be resolved. What benefit would the conservationists get out of saying that the Minister had said that Mr Hawke's new federalism policy was just `crass politics'? I do not believe that the conservationists would get anything out of it. So I do not know why they would have made such a statement if it were not the truth.

I can understand what Mrs Kelly could get out of it. As has already been indicated, she is a keen supporter of Mr Keating. So she could get something out of it if she were not telling the truth. She could have made the point at that meeting that it was just `crass politics' by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I am not in any way accusing the Minister of telling lies. I am just saying to her: prove it; produce the tapes.

One of the conservationists, Ms Siewert, has said that she believed the meeting was private. However, the Minister brought the meeting to the attention of the public by claiming that the conservationists had not advanced any grievances. Again, they said that that was not true-they had advanced their grievances. It was the Minister who first brought that so-called private meeting into the public arena. It is the conservationists who now say, `Produce the tape. We have no objection at all if you produce that tape and make public who was right and who was wrong'. As I have said, unless the truth is established, the conservationists will be under a cloud. The Prime Minister will also be under a cloud and so will the Minister.

Why will the Prime Minister not produce the tape? Is it because he really does believe that the Minister was rubbishing him at a private meeting with the conservationists? Is it because he is terrified to make it public that yet another Minister has been undermining him behind his back at a private meeting? Is that why he will not produce the tape? Is that why he says that he will not listen to the tape because he has better things to do?
Senator Robert Ray made a slip, which was picked up by Senator Baume, when he said that the staff had listened.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think it was a slip?

—I thought it was one and the same thing. Senator Baume thought it was one and the same thing until Senator Ray pointed out that no, they are not one and the same thing-they are vastly different. One is listening to the tape and the other is reading a transcript. We might be naive on this side but we thought it was one and the same thing. It did not even enter our heads that it could have been doctored-but it certainly entered the head of Senator Ray. He pointed out very quickly to us that it was not a matter of listening to the tape; it was reading the transcript. He pointed out very quickly, forcefully and forthrightly that there was a vast difference; that we should not say that it was a matter of listening to the tape; that we should clarify the matter; that it was a matter of reading the transcript. We might be a bit naive because we are used to truth on this side. But it was very obvious that Senator Ray clearly understood the vast difference. If that tape is produced, Senator Ray wants it very clearly identified that the Prime Minister and his staff really did not know what was on it because they looked only at the transcript.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the point I made at the beginning of my speech. I am not accusing the Minister of telling lies. I am not accusing the conservationists of telling lies. But I believe that, until the tape is produced, a cloud hangs over the heads of the conservationists, the Minister and certainly the Prime Minister.

We have to know who has been misleading the House, who has been misleading the Senate. We on this side believe very strongly that truth in politics is of primary importance, not-as the Labor Party believes-that lying is all right so long as one wins an election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few brief words in support of the motion moved by my colleague Senator Michael Baume calling on the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) to produce the taped recording of her discussions last week with eminent conservationists. Much of what I wanted to say has already been said, so I shall be very brief. The reason I intervene in this debate is, importantly, the grave damage Mrs Kelly's reported remarks-unless they are refuted-have done to the Government's whole cause, its new-found supposed conversion to federalism.

SPEECH.PARA: What Mrs Kelly has reportedly done is cast in total doubt the Government's commitment to the federalism that for more than a year has been espoused by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and, therefore, her own Government, and has been the basis of discussions between the Federal and State governments in a series of major Special Premiers Conferences on which the Prime Minister has pinned an enormous amount of his own and the Government's personal credibility. If the Minister for the environment criticised the Government's policies-it does not matter whether she used the words `Prime Minister'-if she criticised the policy of so-called new federalism as crass politics, she was criticising what this Government, since the last election in the middle of 1990, has placed to the forefront in terms of its policy proposals and advances for the future. Mrs Kelly is therefore putting at great risk a policy of the Government of which she is a leading member.

Mrs Kelly has placed at great risk the Government's credibility in relation to its approach to federalism. She has also placed at grave risk several other credibilities. First of all, she has placed her own credibility on the line. Mrs Kelly's credibility is absolutely on the line because, in the absence of evidence, she is asking us to believe that the eminent conservationists in this country with whom she has been having discussions over recent days are lying. Her credibility is absolutely shot if she does not give evidence to refute that situation.

Mrs Kelly has gravely damaged the reputation of those very eminent conservationists. She has put at risk the credibility of the conservation movement in Australia, and she is the Minister responsible for conservation. The Minister's credibility is at risk. The conservationist's credibility is at risk. The Government's supposed approach to federalism is at risk. Therefore, the Prime Minister's credibility is on the line over this. As I said, it is the Prime Minister who has put such an enormous amount of his own personal effort and reputation behind the federalism policies.

Those are four or five very major concerns that the Government, Mrs Kelly, the Parliament and the people of Australia should have. They can all be cleared up very easily and very quickly. All that has to happen is for the Minister to make public-as requested by the Opposition-the taped record of her discussion with the conservationists. The conservationists have said that they have no objection to that. Why on earth, therefore, would Mrs Kelly have any objections to that taping of her discussions being made public if her report of those discussions is correct?

If those tapings are not made public, one can draw at least two conclusions, both of which I believe are very damaging to the whole parliamentary process-the process of democracy in this country. One will only be able to draw the conclusion that either Mrs Kelly is lying or she has deliberately set out, as part of this ongoing bitter leadership fight, to sabotage one of the shopfront, forefront to the public policies of this Government, namely, its approach to federalism. Behind all of that lies the battle of Mr Hawke versus Mr Keating for the prime ministership, because the only way Mr Keating is ever going to become Leader of the Labor Party is to whittle away continually at the Prime Minister's credibility. What stronger way could that be done in a policy sense than to have one of the key supporters of the Keating push for prime ministership undermine-sabotage from within-one of the fundamental Government policies that it has wheeled up for the life of this Parliament?

Indeed, it is ironic but perhaps very understandable that the Minister in this chamber who is obviously going to rise to defend Mrs Kelly and her actions in not releasing the tapes is none other than Senator Richardson. He and Mrs Kelly are two of the very few Ministers in the Hawke Cabinet who are bitterly opposed to the Prime Minister's continuing leadership of the Government and who, over weeks and months, have worked assiduously and unceasingly to change that situation and to install Mr Keating as Prime Minister.

Many credibilities and reputations are on the line. If the tape of the proceedings is not released, not only will all of those credibilities suffer grievously but, as a result, the whole parliamentary process will suffer grievously. The short and long term implications of that for the people of Australia are very serious.
