SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, as I understand the situation, the tape was used by a departmental officer for the purpose of advising the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) on what follow-up action had to occur as a result of events at the meeting. Naturally enough, in the course of--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting follow-up action, isn't it?

—We will get to that. During whatever occurred at that meeting, one would not know what was said by the Minister or other participants and what was said about others. I am not sure that it would be terribly edifying, if that private meeting were to become public, for everyone to know what every person in the room had to say about not just those in the room but those who were anywhere else.
—Are you defending Mrs Kelly or Bob Hawke?
—I am defending both of them.
—God help both of them!

—My assistance to both of them has not done a lot of harm over the years. If one has a look at the two careers, one can see that my assistance to them has not done them a lot of harm. So, if I were Senator Baume, I would not make interjections like that.
—You have made them both what they are, have you?

—No; I have been a contributor to Mr Hawke's career and a contributor to Mrs Kelly's. I might say that they have risen a lot further than those making the interjections. We have heard a lot about discontent in my Party and the assertion that that is what this debate is all about. I should have thought that, in listening to Mr Chaney today, we were hearing a lot more about what is actually happening in the Liberal Party. He is far more worried about Senator Crichton-Browne and what he is up to than anything that is occurring in the leadership of the Labor Party. I happen to have here a copy of the West Australian of only 6 September. This is hot-off-the-press stuff. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The bitterness between rival senior Liberals Noel Crichton-Browne and Fred Chaney escalated yesterday when both men took to the airwaves to defend their positions.
In a series of media interviews, the two men exchanged barbs publicly for the first time.

It goes on and on; and there is another article on the same matter. The problem for me in trying to go through those two articles and expose the bitter division, which Senator Crichton-Browne says could cost the Liberals government at the next election, is that they have as much relevance to this debate as all the contributions of people such as Senator Short and Senator Macdonald. I would much rather concentrate on the substance of the debate.

In this chamber in very recent times I can recall a debate that concerned Senator Bolkus, as Minister for Administrative Services, tabling documents. In the end the Senate quite correctly made a decision that those documents did not have to be tabled, that there was no reason to force their tabling. In the end, as I also recall, the Minister tabled them in any event. The point was that the Senate got the principle right, and it is that that I hope can still be done here today.

Mrs Kelly has said that nothing she said at that meeting reflected on Federal Government policies or the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), but she has said that certainly she did make remarks that would reflect on some of the States. I do not know the form in which that reflection took place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen to the tape.
—I do not want to listen to the tape. There is no need for me to listen to the tape.
—You should listen to the tape; otherwise you cannot mount a logical debate.

—No, there is absolutely no need. I do know that requests have already gone in for freedom of information access to the tapes. I am told that several requests have gone in, and I am not surprised. I cannot quite understand why the normal processes of government, the normal processes of the Freedom of Information Act, which the Opposition would not have a bar of when in government, did not want to go near--
—We passed it.
—The Opposition in government had the most appalling freedom of information record in the history of this Parliament. It did not want to go anywhere near it.
—It is our Act.

—It is the Opposition's Act which it would not do anything about. Fortunately, largely because of the commitment Senator Gareth Evans had to freedom of information over the previous decade, not only did the Parliament get it but also Australia finished up with legislation that is actually observed. Fortunately, because there is in existence an Act, because people are acting upon that legislation--
—Who has put the charges up to make it prohibitive?

—Order! There are five Opposition senators consistently interjecting. One might be tolerable but five is just too much. Senator Short was listened to in relative silence. I ask Senator Short to treat Senator Richardson with the same respect he was given by listening to what the Minister has to say without interjection.

—If there are requests in for freedom of information, one has to ask oneself why the Senate would seek to bypass the legislation, bypass the normal requests and the period in which the Minister or the Department considers that request before information is released. The only reason to interrupt that process is a political purpose. That has revolved around Senator Chaney's current difficulties--
—Mr Chaney.
—As I have been here with him as a senator for years, Senator Macdonald would appreciate the slip of the tongue.
—Nothing compared with your problems, Richo. You have only 44 votes.

—Senator Kemp is the most consistent interjector in the Senate at all times. There are a few of us who do not sit here just to interject. There are a few of us who attempt to contribute. Senator Kemp ought to try it sometime.
—You are jealous. You ought to wait until you are in Opposition.

—The day I become jealous of Senator Kemp, I will be out at the Gap very quickly, but do not hang by the neck waiting for that day. As I was saying, we have to have a proper reason for going around those freedom of information requests, and we do not have one. All we have from the Opposition is an attempt at politicking on the issue. The Senate has to consider whether the Senator Macdonald contribution of `Let's get in and make the hard decisions; let's get in and quickly have the Tully-Millstream dam' is the real reason behind today's debate or whether there is a genuine reason to have the tape produced by next Monday, as outlined in the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: One can only speculate as to what might be on this tape. But, if Mrs Kelly has cast aspersions upon some people in the States at a private meeting or if other participants in the meeting have done the same thing, one wonders why that should be in the public domain.

The reason one has private meetings is that one can make those comments without their being in the public domain. If the Opposition attempts to just pull the rug out from under the process of ever having a private meeting then the functioning of government is going to become very difficult indeed. But it does not stop there because it goes into the Opposition as well. At what point does one draw a line about producing in public the records of private meetings? One wonders whether there is one honourable senator capable of saying that there is nothing said in private that he or she would mind being in the public arena, because all of us at private meetings--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a spurious irrelevancy.
—It is not. It is at the very heart of this debate because every one of us goes to private meetings and makes statements about what we do--
—To a public group like the Conservation Foundation?
—It is a private meeting. I had the same meetings with them twice the year that Mrs Kelly had.
—At a public meeting!
—It is not a public meeting. In the past it has always been a private meeting and it remains so.
—Stitching up some preferences, were you?

—There is no doubt about the fact that I did talk to environment groups about giving the Labor Party preferences at the last election. There is also not much doubt that we got between 80 and 90 per cent of them.
—Did you offer them anything for it?

—I offered them principle; I offered them consistency; and I offered them good policy. That is what I offered them and that is what they got. We got the preferences-fair exchange. I might say that Australia is the better for it. If there are private discussions between Mrs Kelly and a constituent group-normally these are the representatives of the peak bodies of the conservation movement around Australia and it has been the practice that sometimes the participants will vary from meeting to meeting-it should be, as it has certainly always been the practice, that they are private meetings. If the Opposition says to Mrs Kelly or indeed any Minister that no longer can private meetings be regarded as such, then the capacity of the Government to deal with constituent groups will be severely hampered. It is that which I would hope does not happen.

SPEECH.PARA: Today some honourable senators have attempted to canvass the broader debate. They have tried to turn this into an opportunity simply to comment on the processes of discussions between the Commonwealth and the States on the environment. As the Prime Minister has said, the Commonwealth will be giving up none of its environmental powers at all-not one. What we have is Mrs Kelly's Department holding the tape of a private meeting.

The Senate, for the most crass political reasons-to use a phrase we are hearing a bit of in this debate-is attempting to have the normal freedom of information legislation bypassed by requiring the tape to be produced next Monday. It is very doubtful whether the Senate has got the power to make Mrs Kelly do it. On the assumption that the Senate passes a motion and Mrs Kelly refuses, one wonders where we have got. I suspect that we have not got very far except once again to undermine--

TALK.START.PARA: —She is a woman of principle!
—As a woman of principle she should not produce the tape.
—She wouldn't disregard an order of the Senate.

—When the Senate was passing motions about the bottom of the harbour scheme and they were being ignored, one wonders who had the principle then. I suspect that Senator Macdonald does not want to go into that.
—That was long before my time.
—Almost everything was before his time; that is the problem. But for those of us who have been here longer--
—Deal with today; not tomorrow.

—I actually want to deal with tomorrow because I think what we have to do in the Senate is make sure that legislation which has been passed for the purpose of providing information is adhered to. If requests have gone in-it is not simply a matter of what the Opposition might do but there are certainly those in the gallery who put in requests under the freedom of information provisions-why is it that they cannot be looked at in the normal course of events? If the tape should be produced under FOI, then at the end of the day it gets produced, but only after proper consultation with everyone who made a comment at that meeting and thus might be on the tape. There are many people in that category. Why should they not all be given an opportunity to learn what might be revealed about the things that they said? Why should there not be a reasonable time for all of that to be done before the Minister or the Department makes a decision at the end of what is a proper process that has stood the test of time?

SPEECH.PARA: The only reason advanced here today is the crass political motive of the Opposition which attempts to say that in some way Mrs Kelly has made a remark in the leadership contest. I might say that it is very hard to say anything, think anything or do anything at the moment without the Opposition accusing us of that. I do not worry about the crass politicking of the day; rather, I worry about process. If those opposite interfere with the proper process here they are making a very big mistake indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a delicious irony in the motion which is before us today in that the Opposition is defending the integrity of the environment movement, which is committed to the wider use of Federal powers-something which, of course, is not shared by members of the Opposition. I find that a particularly delicious irony. We have heard Senator Macdonald today, for instance, argue most vehemently that the Federal Government should not use its Federal powers to protect the World Heritage wet tropics area and the Tully-Millstream proposed development.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a certain irony in the remarks made a few moments ago by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), who claimed that he had delivered on the promises of the Australian Labor Party in this respect. At the last election the Australian Conservation Foundation asked the various parties what their position was in relation to precisely this matter-the use of Federal powers. I have here the document in front of me:

ALP: Agreed. In addition it has been prepared to use Commonwealth powers to protect some National Estate areas, and International Treaty powers to protect World Heritage areas. It would consider a referendum addressing the constitutional powers of the Commonwealth over the environment. It has used Foreign Investment Review Board powers to protect Shelburne Bay in Queensland. The ALP was also prepared to use these powers to protect the Wet Tropics and Daintree Rainforest in Queensland . . . .
The ALP, using its foreign investment review powers, would subject the proposal for the CRA coal fired power station in the proposed Mt Lesueur National Park, in WA, to rigorous environmental tests.

Quite clearly, the Government was outlining in there what it proposed in relation to the wider use of Federal powers. I have in front of me the fourth draft of the negotiations which are proceeding between the Commonwealth and the States. We read by contrast under subsection 3.1, Commonwealth responsibilities:

(iii) specifically consult with and (use its best endeavours to) secure the agreement of the States and Territories at First Minister level prior to entering into any international commitments which impose costs or obligations on the States or Territories.
This quite clearly indicates that if a State refused it would not use those powers. The draft goes on:

When ratifying any international agreement on environmental matters, the Commonwealth will include in the instrument of ratification a statement on the manner in which the obligations incurred shall be implemented in Australia. This statement will be consistent with the roles and responsibilities established pursuant to this agreement and may only be made following consultation with the States and Territories at First Minister level.
Again, it is deferring to the States. It continues:
The States and Territories have and will continue to have primary responsibility for the formulation and implementation of policy in relation to environmental matters.

So it goes on in relation to standards and in relation to environmental damage as a consequence of toxic chemicals and the release of waste materials. Again these standards which would be accepted by the States are the standards which would apply. In relation to World Heritage areas the draft document states:

The Commonwealth agrees that it will not take action to nominate areas within a State or Territory, for inscription on the World Heritage list where the nomination is contested by the State or Territory in which the proposed nominated area is located.

The document quite clearly outlines a set of proposals which are completely contrary to the promises made by the Government at the time of the last election, as indicated in its response to the questionnaire which was sent out by the Australian Conservation Foundation.

In speaking in support of the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, I also pointed to the way in which both the media and the Opposition-this has also been alluded to by the Minister-have exploited the differences between the Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) over this issue rather than discussing the substantive issue: the proper protection of the environment. That has a great bearing on the issue of the public interest when it comes to the release of this tape.

By way of example, we see on the front page of this morning's Canberra Times the headline `Kelly refuses to release controversial tape'. We do not see a discussion of the new federalism policy and whether that will better protect or not so well protect the environment but, rather, whether the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, will release the tape. There is a long discussion between Mrs Kelly and Mr Hawke in the second column of the article where we learn that Mr Hawke told Parliament that he had roused Mrs Kelly early on Saturday morning after seeing the newspaper reports:
`Very calmly I picked up the phone and spoke to my Minister', he said.
`I must say I woke her from a well-deserved sleep.

The really important issue-the protection of the environment and the powers that the Federal Government has in that respect and the appropriate use of those powers-is not being addressed by either the Government or the Opposition. Indeed, I think it is fair comment that the Opposition would further weaken the use of those Commonwealth powers-section 51.(i) and section 51.(xx), and the external affairs powers set out in the Constitution.

I indicated earlier that I find it depressing that where there are clear options for the exercise of powers, or indeed any other powers, to be put before the public-on which the public should be able to make up its mind and determine whether it wants, for instance, Mrs Kelly re-elected at the next election because she more closely expresses the concern of the public for the proper exercise of Commonwealth powers over protection of the environment or whether it wants to re-elect the Prime Minister because he is prepared to give away those powers-that distinction is not able to be presented to the public by either the Government or the Opposition. Indeed, the Opposition seeks to exploit that very difference. Mrs Kelly has said:
. . . `I can't be out of kilter with the Prime Minister's initiatives in new federalism'.
`For me to even attempt over-riding legislation, I don't think it would even have the support of the Cabinet in the current spirit of co-operation with the States.

That indicates, unfortunately, part of the way in which our democratic process is not working. It is deeply at fault because the full range of options are not given to the public; they are not available to members of the public to enable them to make up their minds.

Of course, members of the public have a right to know that the Minister for the Environment differs from the Prime Minister in a very important respect if they are going to properly exercise their democratic powers at the next election, or even before the next election, in lobbying the Prime Minister, the Minister or any other member of the Government to change their attitude on new federalism or on any other part of the policy.

That comes to the substantive issue of this motion: whether this tape recording should or should not be released for inspection by the Senate. I agree with the remark made by the Minister that there is a line to be drawn here. Quite clearly, the tape recording of every meeting which occurs in this place should not be made into a public document, into a public disclosure. There are such things as private meetings.

Let us look at this particular meeting. This was a meeting between the Minister for the Environment and persons, not individuals, representing tens of thousands of environmentalists around Australia-representing the peak conservation bodies at the national level and also the peak conservation bodies in each State. For instance, in my State, well over 60 conservation bodies are associated with the Conservation Council of South Australia. Each of those bodies has many hundreds of members. In a sense, this was not a private meeting; it was very much a public meeting at which representatives of the public were talking to the Minister about a very important aspect of policy.

In the same way as an individual attending that meeting on behalf of a conservation body may well have made a tape recording-in my view, quite legitimately-and taken it back to that person's membership and played it to members, so the tape recording made by the Minister, which is, as it were, an accurate set of minutes, in my view, should also be a public document.

TALK.START.PARA: —And she breached that privately by telling fibs about the meeting anyway.

—As Senator Baume has indicated, the further claim which has been made that conservation groups lied about some of the contents of that meeting calls into question the need to make a public disclosure of that tape. I would not draw the very long bow which the Minister has drawn to say that this opens completely a Pandora's box and that it necessarily means that all tape recordings should be disclosed. In this case, there is a very important public interest. In many respects, this was not a very private meeting; it was a very public meeting, attended by people from a large number of organisations, representing a large constituency of the Australian electorate. For those reasons, and for those reasons specifically, we support this motion.

The speech read as follows-

The Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Amendment Bill gives effect to the Government's undertakings to provide an improved benefit under the Defence Force Home Loans Assistance Scheme for those personnel who served in the Middle East. Further, the amendments will recognise other operational service of Defence Force members who choose to revoke their entitlement to the Defence Service Homes loan in order to join the new scheme.

The Defence Force Home Loans Assistance Scheme, now known as Defence HomeOwner, provides a subsidised housing loan of $40,000 for members of the Defence Force who joined after 14 May 1985. Interest on the loan is subsidised to the extent of 40% of the average interest that would ordinarily be payable over the term of the loan; the individual is required to meet the remaining 60%. The scheme commenced operation on 15 May 1991, and to the end of July some 41 loans had been provided by the National Australia Bank, the authorised lender under the scheme.

Defence HomeOwner was essentially designed as a peacetime replacement for the Defence Service Homes scheme, which was closed on 14 May 1985. Defence HomeOwner encourages retention of personnel, and when introduced was not geared to provide a benefit based on war or operational service. Payment of the available interest subsidy is currently linked to completed years of service with a requirement for an initial period of service of six years, for which subsidy is not payable. The existing concession for personnel deployed on operational service in the Gulf is waiver of this six-year basic service period, which is a similar concession to that available under the Defence Service Homes scheme.

The Government recognises that in view of the efforts of our personnel who served in the Middle East during the Gulf War, a revised benefit is appropriate, indeed necessary. Therefore the Government now proposes, as further recognition of these efforts, to provide under Defence HomeOwner a minimum benefit of sixteen years' subsidy, regardless of length of service. Naturally, in the case of those who serve past the sixteen year point subsidy will continue to accrue at the normal rate, to a maximum of twenty years. As widows or widowers of eligible members have the same entitlement that their spouse had accrued at the time of death, the sixteen year benefit of deceased Gulf members will pass to the surviving spouse.

The sixteen year subsidy period was selected because the amount of subsidy payable over this period equated to the subsidy payable on a Defence Service Homes loan. This was based on present values and the interest rate applying at the time of the Government's decision.

Another change introduced by this Bill is the waiver of the six-year basic eligibility period for Defence Force personnel with operational service prior to the Gulf War who revoke their entitlement to a Defence Service Homes loan in favour of Defence HomeOwner. Under the Defence Service Homes scheme, members with operational service have no basic qualifying period, and it is considered that this benefit should be applicable to personnel with operational service whichever home loan scheme the serving member chooses.

A further amendment re-defines the Middle East operational area for the purposes of the Act to include Iraq and Kuwait in accordance with the declaration made at the commencement of the ground war. It also sets a cut-off date of 9 June 1991 for operational service in that area.

Precise costing of providing the sixteen year subsidy to Defence Force personnel with Gulf service is not possible, because each year of service offsets one year of subsidy, and it is difficult to estimate how many years each member will serve. This legislation provides additional housing loan benefits to members of the Defence Force who have served their country on operational service as a member of Australia's contingent in the recent Gulf crisis, and builds on the worthwhile and effective scheme introduced earlier in the year by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Loan Bill (No. 2) 1991 is essentially a machinery Bill. It is standard procedure for authorising the financing of an expected deficit of the Consolidated Revenue Fund. The point that needs to be made at the outset is that the need for this Bill would not have arisen if the Government had not completely abrogated any pretence at responsible economic management.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is now in the midst of the largest fiscal deterioration since at least the early 1950s and arguably in our history. Over a period of two short years, there has been a deterioration in the Budget outcome of almost $13 billion. It has gone from a surplus of $8 billion in 1989-90 to an expected deficit of $4.7 billion in the current year. In fact, after taking into account the important transactions that are described as `below the line' and which therefore do not appear in the Budget-but which all have the same impact on the economy-the effect of the public sector on economic activity is worse than the headline `Budget deficit' suggests.

Adjusting for asset sales, transfer of maturing debt to the States, net payments from government business enterprises' superannuation and profit transfers from the Reserve Bank and the Commonwealth Bank, the underlying Budget deficit is about $10.7 billion in 1991-92. Compared with an underlying Budget surplus of $6.4 billion in 1989-90, there has, on that measurement, been an overall fiscal deterioration over the past two years of some $17 billion.

As a result of the Government's failure to control its spending, the expected deficit on the Consolidated Revenue Fund by 30 June 1992 is $10.2 billion. That deficit will be partly due to the official Budget deficit of $4.7 billion and partly because of some `off-Budget' capital transactions. Hence it is likely that some $5.5 billion could be required from the Loan Fund in this financial year.

Because the Loan Bill is a financing measure, the coalition will not be opposing it. However, I make it perfectly clear that our willingness to let the Bill pass can in no way be construed as endorsement of the Government's policy or its means of attempting to handle the terrible predicament it has created for itself. Indeed, the Government can only be condemned for its abject failure.

At a time when Australia is crying out for national leadership, all Government members can do is fight amongst themselves over who should lead the tattered remains of the Australian Labor Party. At a time when every effort should have been put into establishing the right climate for investment and jobs on a sustainable basis, this Budget is reduced to an exercise in protecting one job-the job of the failing Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Given the long term damage to the lives of millions of average Australians which the Government has caused, it is difficult to rationalise or comprehend how a party which calls itself the Labor Party and which once had a reputation-now nothing more than a distant memory-for concern for the well-being of working people could become such an instrument of destruction. That is an irony which must be profoundly depressing to philosophers of the labour movement.

But that does not seem to concern members of this Government. For one reason, they are not philosophers; for another, their focus is on preserving political power and their privileges, not on the well-being of average Australians. Why else would they have so callously thrown one million people out of work?

Nobody has made a greater mess of economic management over the past 60 years than this Government. Its recent Budget worsens the underlying problems because it does nothing to encourage savings, investment and, therefore, long term job creation. For that reason, on behalf of the Opposition, I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) engineering the worst economic recession for 60 years;
(b) knowingly putting over one million people out of work;
(c) its economic mismanagement and fiscal irresponsibility revealed in the Budget;
(d) failing to create a climate for increased national savings, investment, growth and jobs;
(e) not curtailing its own purpose spending, running a reckless deficit and plundering the savings of households and firms; and
(f) providing no leadership, no example and no hope to the people of Australia''.

The recent Budget fails to recognise the underlying problems of the economy. It certainly does not do anything to correct the basic causes of the economic mess which the Government has created. The evidence of that mess is all around us. It is mainly due to the fact that, under Labor, savings and investment have collapsed. As a result, so have jobs and living standards.

Look at what has happened to job vacancies. Opportunities for work have been destroyed by this Government's policy failure. Two years ago the ratio of job vacancies per 1,000 unemployed was 145 : 1. The job vacancies ratio is now 32 : 1. Two years ago, the number of job vacancies was 69,500; it is now 25,700-a fall of more than two-thirds. This Government's incompetence has wrecked the business environment. If honourable senators have any doubts about that, they should go and talk to any firm which is struggling to survive under the yoke of this Government and ask them what they think of Labor. The number of bankruptcies has soared from 7,000 in 1989 to 16,000 this year and they are still rising. There is little prospect of new investment and employment with business being clobbered by such a bizarre caricature of a government as the economic vandals now in power.

Living standards have actually fallen under Labor. Average Australians are worse off now than when Labor came to government. In real terms, an average Australian family-a husband on full time average weekly earnings; a wife working part time on one-third of average weekly earnings; plus two children-is 2.7 per cent worse off in 1991 than it was in 1983. Were it not for the family allowance payments-which are transfer payments and do not represent an increase in national wealth as such-the real fall in living standards for the average family would be almost 5 per cent. So living standards have fallen for those average families-and they are average families who are doing well because they have jobs. Living standards have been absolutely decimated for those who have been thrown onto the scrap heap of unemployment due to Labor's policy failures.

This Government has failed abjectly. The fundamental reason for this failure is the Government's inability to understand that an economy cannot grow without a level of domestic savings sufficient to sustain that growth. The most important economic problem Australia now faces is the low level of savings. Without savings there can be no investment. That is a basic fact of life that seems not to have dawned on those opposite, many of whom still seem to believe that money comes from taxes.

For Australia merely to sustain the minimum economic growth rate of 3 per cent required just to absorb new entrants into the labour force, let alone provide real per capita growth, we need to invest at least 25 per cent of national output. But total spending on fixed capital accounted for only 21.8 per cent of gross domestic product last year, a shortfall of some 15 to 20 per cent, and is expected to fall further over the current year. As a result we are going backwards; we are losing ground. Far from achieving a growth rate of 3 per cent, which is the bare minimum required, there is virtually no growth.

It is not hard to see why. The net operating surplus of firms-what they have left to invest after covering costs and paying taxes-has plummeted. In the year to June just ended it fell by 6 per cent. Under Labor the profit share of gross domestic product has deteriorated ever since it came into office. Labor of course does not like profits. It does not like the idea of investors getting a return on their capital. That is a fundamental part of Labor's ideological baggage. That is why the economic policy failures that we have seen throughout the past years of Labor government are there.

The Prime Minister claimed three weeks ago in the House of Representatives that `company profits as a share of GDP are still above the long term average of the last 15 years', but-not for the first time-he has wilfully misled the Australian Parliament and the people. The truth, according to the Government's own Budget Papers, is that when account is taken of the impact of company tax and interest payments, the profit share as a proportion of GDP is now at its lowest level for over 20 years. That is shown in Budget Paper No. 1, pages 2.24 and 2.25.

With such a fall-off in net surplus or profits, investment has inevitably plunged. Private gross fixed capital expenditure fell by 13.7 per cent last year and is expected by the Government to fall a further 6 per cent in real terms in 1991-92. I believe that expectation is conservative. For more than a year business has been telling the Government that it is badly underestimating the downturn in business investment spending. For 1991-92 the firm of Syntec, which has a very good track record in the forecasting area, estimates a real contraction in business investment of 18 per cent. If it is right, or even near the mark, the fall in business investment over the past two years will approach 30 per cent. Such a dramatic collapse would be a national crisis. For over a million people it already is. The lesson of these events is the immutable link between profits, savings and investment. That may not suit the ideology of the Labor Party, but it cannot be denied or avoided.

What, then, is happening to the level of savings under Labor? The household savings ratio has now fallen to 4 per cent. That is the lowest figure ever recorded. Total savings for the nation as a proportion of gross domestic product have fallen from 25 per cent in 1983-84 to 21.9 per cent in 1990-91-a fall again of about 10 to 15 per cent.

The fall in Australia's savings has been the largest since the 1950s. With that collapse in savings, where will the investment funds come from? Without a fundamental diversion of funds away from consumption into productivity-improving investment, there will either be a fall in Australian investment or more capital inflow from abroad. Given the parlous state of our balance of payments, borrowing more money from overseas cannot be considered as an ongoing solution to the problems which this Government has created. Our net foreign liabilities already stand at $177 billion, a twentyfold increase over the past eight to 10 years. Of the $177 billion, foreign-owned equity is $47 billion and the debt factor is $130 billion.

Servicing that debt will place massive demands on the Australian economy for many years into the future. Paying off the mortgage is the legacy which this selfish and shortsighted government has left to the Australians of the future, to our children and our grandchildren. The cost of servicing our foreign debt is today running at $17 billion a year, or some 4.5 per cent of our total national product.

The stark fact is that at least 4.5 per cent of what Australians produce at present is not available for use by Australians. Instead, it must be converted into another currency and sent overseas to pay for the debt that has been accumulated by the disastrous economic policies of this Government. It is about time that the Government came clean with the people of Australia about the disaster it has caused.

Finally, I ask rhetorically: what do consumers think about the outlook under Labor? I have talked about investors and savers, but in regard to consumers the latest Westpac-Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research index of consumer sentiment shows that people are pessimistic. Can one blame them? They are now more pessimistic about their own financial situation and about the prospect of improvements in the economy in the coming year. The inescapable fact is that average Australians do not have confidence in Labor. Labor has lost the confidence of the people. It is incapable of making the necessary reforms to encourage investment and restore Australia to growth and prosperity. The 1991 Budget, the deficit in which is the reason for the Loan Bill we are now debating, is a disaster for business confidence, for investment and therefore inevitably for both existing employment and job creation in Australia for a very long time to come.

For that reason, although the Opposition does not oppose this Bill it feels very strongly about the amendment that it has moved to the second reading. In particular, it once again draws the attention of this Parliament and the Australian people to the cruel hard fact that the policies of this Government have put more than one million people out of work. When the family factor is taken into account, those policies have devastated many millions of Australians. They have condemned them to a hardship that will be an almost intractable problem to solve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate today is debating the Loan Bill (No. 2) 1991. This is the second Loan Bill to be debated this calendar year because of the decline in the Government's fiscal position during the Government's own recession. This collapse in economic activity meant that loan funds were needed at the end of the last financial year, even though the Government achieved a surplus approaching $2 billion for the year as a whole. The absence of a Loan Bill during previous years reflects the fact that the Commonwealth has been running substantial surpluses since 1987-88, but the purpose of this Bill is to make provision for the financing of the prospective 1991-92 Budget deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: The technical necessity for this Bill is not strictly related to whether the Budget is in surplus or deficit. Rather, it is necessary to balance a projected deficit in the Commonwealth Consolidated Revenue Fund. We are always told that the Consolidated Revenue Fund must not end the year in deficit. Indeed, the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) states:
Legally, expenditure from the Consolidated Revenue Fund cannot exceed the moneys available to that Fund.

I must say that the exact legal reason for this is unclear, and certainly I have not been able to find any explanation for that statement. I ask the Minister to state the exact legal necessity in order to clarify this matter.

The Consolidated Revenue Fund is created by section 81 of the Australian Constitution, and all revenues or moneys raised or received by the Government must be deposited in that account. Even though this wording clearly covers loans raised by the Commonwealth, when the Audit Act was passed in 1901 it created both a loan fund, through section 55, and a trust fund, through section 60. There is, therefore, one main bank account called the Commonwealth Public Account. However, transactions are recorded in three separate accounts: the Consolidated Revenue Fund, the Loan Fund and the Trust Fund. In the first 10 years of Federation only the Consolidated Revenue Fund and the Trust Fund operated.

The first Loan Act was passed in 1911. From this time until the Second World War, all recurrent revenue and expenditure were channelled through the Consolidated Revenue Fund, whilst all loan raising and capital expenditure were conducted through the Loan Fund. As I said before, some explanation of the necessity for raising loan funds in this way would be appropriate.

Clause 5 of the Bill specifies that the expenditure to be made from the Loan Fund is defence expenditure; that is, any defence expenditure otherwise authorised by the Parliament which is incurred after the Bill receives royal assent may be made from the Loan Fund rather than the Consolidated Revenue Fund, thereby reducing or eliminating any deficit which may otherwise occur in that account. The reason defence expenditure is used to effect the appropriation is twofold: firstly, the defence budget is always large-in fact, the Australian Democrats believe that it is far too large; and, secondly and most importantly, clause 4, which grants the Treasurer the right to borrow money necessary to finance the expenditure authorised by clause 5, avoids the necessity for obtaining the approval of the Loan Council for the borrowings for defence purposes, which could indeed be politically embarrassing.

Part 3 of the Bill-clauses 6 and 7- authorises the Treasurer to borrow money to supplement any deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund which may arise. It is not yet certain whether this authority will be necessary this year. All such moneys are to be applied to the Consolidated Revenue Fund except for that amount relating to the expense of borrowing.

The Loan Bill (No. 2) 1991 is not opposed by the Australian Democrats since the Bill is merely a technical machinery measure rather than a substantive one. The substantive measures in the Government's financial and fiscal policy have been announced in the recently delivered, and universally condemned, Commonwealth Budget. With one million unemployed one could have expected a Labor Treasurer to have introduced a range of measures to boost the economy and to reduce unemployment. Instead, he is budgeting for higher unemployment-an average of 10.5 per cent; a declining job market-down 1.75 per cent; a further decline in household savings; and, indeed, a collapse in private investment.

There are no measures that seek to redress that in the short, medium or long term. The intelligent society is further away. Modest additional funds for tertiary institutions are welcome; but, to pay for these, higher cost barriers have been erected against students-an increase of $144m to the tertiary tax. However, none of this amounts to anything like a clear economic strategy to get Australia out of the recession, and the new Treasurer is proving that he can bear the misfortunes of others with great calm and fortitude.

The Liberal and National parties should be pleased. Their economic policy is in good hands. It is quite clear that, despite the statements Senator Short made at the Wailing Wall about the policies of the Government and their destructive social and economic effects, there are no measures the Opposition parties are putting forward that have any chance of addressing the coming calamitous situation. They would go even further: they would deregulate further; they would cut services; they would reduce public expenditure; they would not provide incentives for industry; they would not provide incentives for exports; they would not increase funds for research; they would not increase funds for education.

In these circumstances, the Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion is hypocritical, to say the least. Certainly the Australian Democrats could support paragraphs (a), (b), (c), (d) and (f). They merely state the obvious-that the Government has engineered a recession and that the Australian people are suffering as a result. However, paragraph (e) says that the Government should be condemned for not curtailing its own purpose spending, running a reckless deficit and plundering the savings of households and firms.

While the savings of households and firms certainly have gone down the drain in large measure, it is entirely hypocritical for the Opposition to condemn the Government for not pump-priming the economy even further. I would go the other way. It is absolutely essential that the Government adopt an interventionist strategy to get us out of this current mess, and the do-nothing attitude of the Opposition is to be condemned. At the appropriate time I will move an amendment to delete paragraph (e) from the Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion.

The Democrats have put forward a number of proposals, which I briefly mentioned before. They are echoed more and more by both economic analysts and commentators, who believe that we must move away from the do-nothing free market ideology which condemns us to do nothing while a million Australians are unemployed. I believe that they are also echoed in what the Australian Council of Trade Unions congress has proposed. I believe that the coalition parties should consider carefully before they condemn out of hand constructive proposals that would enable the Australian economy to be boosted and jobs to be provided.
The Australian Democrats will support the Loan Bill (No. 2). As I have foreshadowed, I move:
1. Omit paragraph ``e''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is the latter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially new taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this Budget was framed to keep the Prime Minister in his job. It does not worry about the jobs of the one million Australians who are unemployed. The reason this Bill comes before the chamber today was outlined by my colleague Senator Short, who mentioned the enormous blow-out in the Government's funding requirement. Despite that blow-out, we would not have had to have this Bill before the Parliament had it not been for our colleagues in the Senate chamber in 1985 and 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: The sixth edition of Odgers, which we have all been particularly gratified to receive recently, points out that in 1985 and 1986 the Government sought permanent authority for these loan Bills. Each time that permanent authority was rejected by the Senate. It is useful to read through this current loan Bill to make sure that the Government is not seeking any permanent authority to borrow. It is quite clear that, under the policies of this Hawke Government, we will continue to borrow until its demise.

Senator Spindler on behalf of the Australian Democrats raised some points about their own policies. It is well-known in this chamber that the policies of the Australian Democrats are high taxing policies. I think there are some 40 to 50 new revenue measures in the alternative Budget presented to the press by Senator Spindler. The Australian Democrats want to raise an additional $6.4 billion. He says in that alternative Budget that he wishes to spend an additional $6.4 but, as we discovered when we looked through that alternative Budget, there is a $2.4 billion black hole or miscalculation in it.

Essentially, I want to speak about the problems with the Government's policies. They have been effectively outlined in the amendments proposed by Senator Short. I wonder how many Australian Labor Party people-especially Senator Bolkus, who is leaving the chamber, and Senator Cook-know that, faced with a similar problem in 1945 Mr Chifley, the then leader of the Party, presented a White Paper to the Parliament entitled Full Employment in Australia. Does Senator Cook believe it? At that time the Government was faced with the problem of a war economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your party opposed it at the time. I remember it well.

—They were also faced with a history of more than 10 per cent unemployment during the 1920s and 1930s. The old Labor Party-not the new Labor Party-committed itself to a policy of full unemployment. In 1945, the Labor Party of old brought down a White Paper. I must admit that there were many problems associated with that White Paper, but the important thing is that it expressed the key value that full employment is vital in a modern economy for a variety of reasons that I shall be pointing out.

SPEECH.PARA: What did the Labor Party do today? What did Senator Cook's Caucus do today? It did not propose a proper White Paper, a proper Government policy and a decent Budget to promote employment in this country. Today, it appointed Lloyd O'Neil. Quite rightly Senator Cook looks surprised. I had never heard of Lloyd O'Neil. However, he was appointed to head a Caucus committee of seven to investigate the causes of unemployment. The Labor Party of old under Chifley brought down a big White Paper titled Full Employment in Australia. Under the new Labor Party, Lloyd O'Neil will be carrying out a Caucus investigation into the causes of unemployment.

If one ever wanted to see a symbol of how the Labor Party has fallen, that is the symbol. There is a very clear reason for that. The present level of unemployment has been created by eight years of government by this Labor Party. Its senior Ministers have admitted that. It is astonishing that Senator Spindler comes into this chamber and tells honourable senators to start looking at the prescriptions of the ACTU. Senator Cook will confirm that comrade Ferguson, the President of the ACTU, has said on a number of occasions--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not your comrade.

—Senator Coates calls Mr Ferguson comrade. He is certainly not my comrade. That is absolutely for sure. He is not my comrade, nor is he the comrade of the one million Australians who are without jobs.
—I am happy to call him comrade.

—He is Senator Coates's comrade. That is absolutely right. As comrade Ferguson has said, he is part and parcel of this Government. Senator Cook will not query that. Every major policy has been checked and cleared through the ACTU. When comrade Ferguson and comrade Kelty-or comrade Crean as he then was-said no, that brought those Government policies to a halt, including the goods and services tax. The Prime Minister and the alternative Prime Minister, whom Senator Cook supports, namely, Mr Keating, are on record as being very strongly supportive of that tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point that I wish to make is that we are seeing the example of the new Labor Party-the Labor Party of the spivs, the Labor Party of the wealthy corporate bosses and the Labor Party of every vested interest group-that has dropped its traditional base. Under Chifley, the traditional base of the Labor Party was working class Australians, and it committed itself to looking after their interests.

How far has the Labor Party travelled under this Government's policies? I am glad that Senator Cook is in the chamber. This Labor Party Government has cut the living standards of Australian workers. On a number of occasions I have pointed out that the living standards of Australian workers have been cut savagely by this Government's policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your selective statistics.
—Not selective statistics, but based on the definition that Senator Cook gave in this chamber. Quite rightly he is embarrassed by it, because it is an absolute disgrace that that happened.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the 1980s the Labor Party Government cut the living standards of Australian workers. But that was not good enough for it. What is the Government doing now? It is throwing them out of jobs. That is what its policies have done. That is why I say that this is not the Labor Party of old. This is not the Labor Party of the Chifleys and the Curtins. This is the Labor Party of the new spivs and the corporate rich. It is the Labor Party of the Hawkes, the Keatings, the Cooks and even Senator Coates. I must say that, on occasions, Senator Coates rises in this chamber and grudgingly defends that disastrous Party and its disastrous policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested to hear you supporting the Chifley Government.

—I supported the commitment of the Chifley Government to full employment and jobs. But who did the Labor Party Government appoint? It appointed Lloyd O'Neil to tell it what was wrong with it. Let me tell the Labor Party that it does not need Lloyd O'Neil to tell it that. One has only to open any newspaper and read what any economist says. One of the central reasons for this disastrous recession, which is the worst since the Great Depression, is this Government's arrangements, its policies and its accord with the trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: What are comrade Ferguson and comrade Kelty reported as saying yesterday at the ACTU conference? I ask honourable senators to remember that that organisation was part and parcel of this Government. When the Budget came down, comrade Ferguson was asked whether he was critical of the Budget. But not comrade Ferguson! He was true blue. He was part and parcel of this Government, and one must give him credit for that. Yesterday, comrade Ferguson said that he had discovered that unemployment levels in this country-now one million people-were `intolerable and unacceptable'. It took him a hell of a long time, with one million workers out of a job, to find out that the levels are intolerable and unacceptable. I stress that this is the man who played an essential role in the policy development of this Government. Now, before his conference, he has the cheek to stand up and complain about those policies. He should have complained three or six years ago when it was absolutely blatantly obvious that this crisis was going to be upon us. But no, finally, even comrade Ferguson has broken ranks and said that the unemployment levels are intolerable and unacceptable.

In recent months, honourable senators have witnessed the collapse in Eastern Europe of institutions that have been around for a long time-70 years in the case of the Communist Party and in many other countries since the Second World War. They were rotten to the core, but pretended to represent the interests of the people whom they so manifestly did not represent. I wonder whether we can draw any analogy with those developments.

This Labor Party is not a party of the workers. It is a party of the powerful and the privileged. I wonder how long Australian workers are going to stay with a party that has cut their living standards and lost their jobs. Senator Cook has been part of that history. In the mornings when he reads headlines about Eastern Europe, I wonder whether he sometimes gets a little hint that maybe the Labor Party is heading down that same road.

It is about time that this country had a union movement that represented the interests of workers not union bosses. When the election is held in four months time or six months time-even if the Labor Party tries to string out its term until 1993-as it rings out this Government, it will be ringing out the ACTU as well. The ACTU will pay a very heavy price indeed for being part and parcel of this disgraceful Government, which has cut the living standards of Australian workers and caused catastrophic unemployment.

I invite Senator Cook to see what gross hypocrisy, and what an aimless, pathetic group of people, we now have. I invite him to read through the debates in 1982. He should go to his database and get his huge staff-a few of those highly paid consultants-to tap out the debates on unemployment in 1982. He should pull out those debates because they are very interesting. He would see what Mr Hawke, his Prime Minister, and Mr Keating, his preferred Prime Minister, said about unemployment. Let me take one quote from Mr Hawke.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let's compare Fraser with Hawke.
—Senator Cook should not get excited. Let me read one choice quote from Mr Hawke, which is absolutely accurate, I am happy to say. This is what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government-
and he was not referring to his Government-
has consistently misrepresented to the Australian community both the dimensions and the causes of unemployment in this country.
Senator Cook should tune into this:

For this growing legion of unemployed the immediate personal devastation of their predicament must be bitter enough. I refer to the loss of income, the loss of capacity to satisfy their aspirations and the needs of those dependent upon them, the loss of status in the eyes of family, neighbours and friends and, worst of all, in many cases the erosion of their own self-esteem.
That is what Mr Hawke said in 1982. What was the level of unemployment then?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 10.4 per cent.
—It was 7.4 per cent.
—Tell us the participation rate figure.

—Senator Cook is pathetic. We are talking about one million people unemployed and the Minister for Industrial Relations pathetically calls out, `Tell us the participation rate'. He is absolutely pathetic.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what Mr Hawke said then, and unemployment is such that there are now hundreds of thousands more people on the dole. Mr Hawke postured around the country and proposed these solutions. Senator Cook should read Mr Hawke's proposal to solve that problem in 1982-a problem caused by a very great recession in world trade and the worst drought in living memory. It was not, I am proud to say, caused by a government that planned a recession, as this Government did.

This is not the Labor Party of old. This is a new Labor Party which has lost touch with its own interests, has lost touch with the national interest. That is why I strongly support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Short. I look forward to the Minister standing up and at last starting to address the devastating problem that we have in this country. And do not roll out Lloyd O'Neil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Loan Bill (No. 2) 1991 is the second Loan Bill in the past six months which the Senate has had to address. It is indeed a pity that the Government has not been able to maintain its past good record of Budget surpluses, which required no loan Bills for the three years from 1988 to 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet, Mr Acting Deputy President, I put it to you and to fellow senators gathered here today that the Government has only itself to blame as the factors which have led to the need for this Loan Bill have arisen as a direct consequence of Government policy. The recession we had to have, courtesy of the honourable member for Blaxland, Mr Keating, and the other economic decision makers of the Labor Party, has placed the Government in the deficit situation that has led to this Bill.

The Loan Bill (No. 2) 1991 will allow certain Commonwealth expenditures to be met from the Loan Fund rather than from the Consolidated Revenue Fund. We are told that the Bill arises because the Government expects the Consolidated Revenue Fund to be in deficit to the extent of about $10.2 billion by the end of this financial year. This deficit will occur partly because of the Budget deficit of $4.7 billion and partly because of off-Budget capital transactions.

I put to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I would be pleased if the Government could provide the Senate during this debate with a breakdown of the off-Budget expenses estimated at $5.5 billion for the year between, firstly, transactions of a financing nature being related to the raising or discharge of a loan or comprising transactions involving financial assets and liabilities; secondly, contributions to the national debt sinking fund and the loan consolidation and investment reserve; and, thirdly, superannuation payments made by the Commonwealth to the employees of Commonwealth business undertakings.

I am uncertain as to whether the Government wishes to review its Budget deficit of $4.7 billion in the light of its backing down on the Medicare levy of $3.50 and/or any further changes it may be considering to what was already an unimaginative, unconstructive and uninspiring Budget. Hopefully, the Government will at least admit that $4.7 billion does not represent the actual deficit. The actual deficit has been estimated at $7.7 billion, from which Mr Kerin then deducted $625m from asset sales and some $2.3 billion from the transfer to the States of the responsibility for financing their maturing debt.

However, this is not the only aspect of the Budget to have changed since 21 August. Mr John Kerin, the honourable member for Werriwa and Treasurer, stated that the fundamental objective of the Government's macro-economic policy is to achieve a solid and sustainable rate of economic growth. The important elements in achieving this are listed as generating enduring employment growth; ensuring that the gains made on inflation are sustained and built upon; and reducing the current account deficit and stabilising our external debt relative to GDP. The Budget Papers then go on to say that achieving these goals will require a coordinated and consistent policy response embracing all arms of macroeconomic policy and industry reform. The Government says it wants to do this but then does not include anything in its Budget to ensure that these objectives will be achieved.

Let us look at fiscal policy for a moment. I mentioned before the Budget deficit, which for argument's sake we will put at $4.7 billion. Running a deficit puts the Government back into the money market, competing with the private sector for funds and thus putting pressure on the interest rate. Such a move is contrary to the Government's previous fiscal policy, where it purposely moved itself out of the borrowing market so that funds were available for the private sector to invest and thus to create employment. On this basis I do not see how fiscal policy would help the Government's objective to generating enduring employment growth.

There is certainly no wages policy identifiable in the Budget. Contrary to media speculation before the Budget, there was no 4 per cent or 5 per cent rate as agreed with the ACTU before the Budget. The Government is probably still trying to work out where accord 6 has left it and where it goes from there.

The one positive sign as far as the coalition is concerned is that the Government has listed, as a central issue for the AIRC and the parties involved in the forthcoming review of wages principles, how best to develop further a workable framework for enterprise bargaining. We on this side of the Senate have been advocating a move to enterprise bargaining for some time, although not as a second tier for wage negotiations, as the ACTU would suggest. If the Government is serious about its objective to contain inflation then it cannot afford to build in a percentage wage increase each year which acts purely as a fillip for the inflation spiral. This much, I hope, it has realised. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The town of Theodore is a small rural town in central Queensland. It has a population of 600 people, with 900 people in the surrounding district, which includes an Aboriginal community. There are two small shops and two hotels. It is suffering from the drought and the recession that is affecting the rest of Australia. For some years, people needing health care have been served by a doctor who was appointed as the Medical Superintendent of the Theodore Hospital. This is a part time position and because the town has a population of only 1,500, it can support only one doctor. He has given exemplary care to the people of that community for some years.

SPEECH.PARA: Due to his desire to improve the rural health care throughout Queensland and that district, in particular, he became active within the Rural Doctors Association of Queensland. He became Secretary and, subsequently, President of the Rural Doctors Association of Queensland. In occupying that role, of course, he criticised government and had a certain amount of press exposure in relation to criticism of government and other organisations.
On 8 August 1991, he received a letter from the Labor Minister for Health in the Queensland Government. It reads:
Dear Dr. . .

Your most recent attacks on the Queensland Government follow a series of similar public criticisms of the Government in which you have resorted to untruths and distortions to create apprehension and uncertainty in the community about the policies of the Government.

Clearly, I can no longer have confidence in your ability to implement the policies of the Government as an employee of the Central Regional Health Authority. I have spoken to you on at least two occasions to remind you of your responsibilities in this regard. The first time was when you were officially summonsed to my office in this regard on Tuesday 11 December, 1990. The second occasion was in Emerald on Friday 31 May, 1991 at the Central Regional Medical Superintendents Conference.

The Director General of Queensland Health has also reprimanded you in response to certain public statements which he considered to be unacceptable from an employee of the Government. This occurred in Brisbane on Tuesday 11 December, 1990 and in Rockhampton on Tuesday 25th June, 1991.
I enclose a list of media statements by you which documents what I consider to be a sustained campaign of criticism of Government policy.

As you have obviously determined to maintain a role as a constant critic of the Government, I think it is only fair that you be relieved of any responsibility to the public sector so that there can be no ongoing suggestion of divided loyalties. You will then be in a position to say whatever you will about the Government and the elected members of the Government.
In view of all the circumstances then, I think it best that you tender your resignation as Medical Superintendent of Theodore Hospital.
Your advice, in due course, will be appreciated.
Yours faithfully
K. V. McElligott MLA
MINISTER FOR HEALTH

What an extraordinary situation! It is interesting that in today's Courier-Mail there is a cartoon of the Queensland Premier, Mr Goss. The caption above the first drawing is, `Charges of racism over ministerial gaffes?!'; above the second is `Charges of cronyism over govt appointees?!'. Then there is a slight distortion of the cartoon of Mr Goss and a caption that says, `Don't you worry about that!'. I have inserted my own caption, `Charges of arrogance over criticism?!'.

The law in Queensland allows any public servant to stand in an election campaign and retain his or her position if unelected. There is no limitation on freedom of speech. However, the action of this particular Minister-and the Government, which obviously endorsed that situation-for the first time in mid-term shows the true arrogance of the Goss Labor Government. It is unbelievable that this doctor had no alternative but to resign from the position because of his devotion to the people of Theodore and the fact that it would be extremely difficult to get another doctor to go there in light of the circumstances.

It is well known that only 23 per cent of doctors in Australia are located in country areas. There is enormous difficulty in getting people to go to small towns such as Theodore. It smacks of a totalitarian government which cannot stand criticism; it is extremely arrogant. Next, of course, we shall see further activities along this line.

It is also interesting that the private secretary of the Minister for Health is a certain Mr David Butt, who was a secretary to Dr Blewett when he was the Minister for Community Services and Health. It is evident that the sensitivity of the current Queensland Minister for Health and the Government has been transferred from the activities of Mr Butt when he occupied the position in Canberra. The whole of the Health Department in Queensland has now been stacked with Labor appointees and it is occurring in other departments as well. There is a notice in the lift of the Queensland Health Department that says, `The Canberra branch of the ALP'.
An old saying that applies to all governments-far be it from me to tell you, Mr Deputy President, but you too were in such a position-is that power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the adjournment this evening to bring to the attention of the Senate the case of Mr Vo Dai Ton. On Saturday 20 July 1991, I had the opportunity to attend the ninth commemorative anniversary of the imprisonment of Vo Dai Ton in Vietnam. This particular function was organised by the Vietnamese Community in Australia (Victoria Chapter). The Vietnamese Community, under its President, Ba Phuc Tran, is engaged in widespread community work in my State and assists Vietnamese families to settle in our country.

SPEECH.PARA: Some hundreds of Vietnamese attended this function, as well as representatives from many other community groups. All the major political parties attended. I was the spokesman on behalf of the Liberal Party of Australia. Dr Andrew Theophanous represented the Australian Labor Party. There were also political representatives from both the State Liberal and Labor parties in attendance. The speeches were unanimous in expressing their concern about Mr Vo Dai Ton, his health and his welfare.

Mr Vo Dai Ton was a former distinguished General in the South Vietnamese army. He came to Australia after 1975 and subsequently became a permanent resident. He was arrested in 1982 after returning to Vietnam from Australia. In other words, for almost nine years Vo Dai Ton has been incarcerated in a Vietnamese prison. At no time has the Vietnamese Government brought him to trial. Mrs Vo Dai Ton has been very active in seeking the release of her husband and has written to the President of Vietnam, Mr Vo Chi Chong. A number of efforts have been made to seek information on Vo Dai Ton and to request his release from prison.

As recently as February this year, the Vietnamese Ministry of Foreign Affairs again assured Australian officials that it was `trying very hard' to arrive at a decision on his release, but that no guarantee of any particular date for such a decision could be made. Again, in April and May of this year, further representations were made to the Vietnamese Ministry of Foreign Affairs. I am pleased to report to the Senate that the coalition shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, Mr Ruddock, has taken a personal and longstanding interest in this particular case. The Australian Government has indicated to the Vietnamese that Vo Dai Ton will be accepted again as an Australian resident.

It is true that the Vietnamese Government has undertaken some reforms which have had some positive effects on human rights in that country. This process, called Doi Moi, began in 1986 and there have been some positive reports. For example, some of those reports have indicated that religious worship is largely tolerated but with some restrictions. Many people who had been detained pursuant to the defeat of the South Vietnamese Government have been released from the re-education camps. A commitment has been made to prevent the torture and ill-treatment of people detained in prison. Finally, there is some increased freedom of the press to report abuses of power by local authorities.

However, it also has to be reported in the Senate that a recent Amnesty International report on human rights indicates that there are still some concerns about the treatment of prisoners. The Vietnamese Minister of Justice recently indicated to our Ambassador that Vietnam's laws were framed in the context of a bitter war and that, with the passage of time, these laws could be relaxed. Mr Deputy President, I suggest the time has come to relax those laws now.

I have risen in the Senate this evening because many Australians and recent Vietnamese settlers have expressed concern to me about the well-being of Vo Dai Ton. The world is changing dramatically; there is widespread recognition throughout the world of the importance of human rights. I hope the Vietnamese Government will enter into this new spirit of cooperation and release Vo Dai Ton. I hope the Australian Government will pursue this cause with great vigour and perseverance.
