QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 15 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a consortium of local companies excluded from bidding for selection as prime contractor for the $300 million contract to set up a two-centre air traffic control system for the whole of Australia in Brisbane and Melbourne; if so, why.
(2) Did the Civil Aviation Authority only invite tenders from six foreign companies for the contract.
(3) What efforts were taken to find a viable Australian enterprise with the capability to fulfil the contract.
(4) Why was no opportunity given to Australian companies to tender for the project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has recognised that it must upgrade a substantial part of its Air Traffic Control (ATC) System, in order to replace ageing equipment and improve the efficiency of its operations.

In planning this upgrade, the CAA was mindful of the difficulties which have been experienced with many ATC development projects around the world in recent years. Cost overruns of hundreds of millions of dollars and schedule slippages amounting to years have occurred on major ATC development projects overseas.

With this knowledge, the CAA adopted a low risk strategy by seeking proven systems and inviting interest only from organisations which have demonstrated success in the implementation, integration and commissioning of complete air traffic systems. This approach significantly reduces the potential for large cost and schedule overruns.

Having adopted this strategy, the CAA assessed that no wholly Australian owned companies had previously implemented, integrated and commissioned complete air traffic systems. However, several multinational companies with Australian subsidiaries have proven records in this area.

(2) In choosing the companies which were invited to register interest in The Australian Advanced Air Traffic System (TAAATS) project, the CAA analysed the comparative credentials and achievements of an extensive list of companies which are in the business of providing and installing complete air traffic systems. To achieve timing requirements the list was pruned to include only those companies which had the greatest potential to provide and install the proven technology the CAA is seeking.

Six overseas companies were invited to register interest in the project on the basis of their potential to provide and install the proven technology the CAA is seeking in the necessary timeframe. These were:
Alenia
Hughes Aircraft Corporation
IBM Australia Limited
NEC Information Systems Australia Pty Ltd
Siemens-Plessey Electronics Systems, Australia
Thomson Radar Australia Corporation Pty Ltd.

Four of the six groups, IBM Australia Limited, Hughes Aircraft Corporation, Thomson Radar Australia Corporation and Siemens-Plessey Electronics Australia, have responded to the CAA's offer to register interest in TAAATS. Three of these companies are Australian subsidiaries of overseas parent companies, and two out of the three employ substantial numbers of Australians. IBM Australia employs around 4200 staff and Siemens-Plessey in excess of 2000 staff.

(3) The CAA is fully conscious of the Government's Australian and New Zealand industry preference policies. However, because of the nature of the large scale system being sought and the lack of Australian suppliers of air traffic systems, it is inevitable that overseas companies will need to supply a major share of the product.

The CAA has advised that, unfortunately, a local industry consortium would not have provided the same security as the approach the Authority has adopted. As no Australian company provides an air traffic control system, it could only be presumed that an Australian consortia would intend to `subcontract' to an overseas company the heart of the system and the consortia provide the periphery. It would seriously increase the risk to the CAA to distance itself from the key portion of the system.

(4) The approach the CAA has taken does not preclude opportunities for Australian industry. The prime contractor selected will be obliged to comply with Australian Government policies regarding offsets and Australian and New Zealand industry preference.

The CAA will also require that a support capability for the selected system is available or established in Australia. Initial assessment of offers now received suggests a significant amount of Australian industry involvement in all offers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 16 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has Australia taken following recent further nuclear tests by the French in the South Pacific.
(2) Has the Minister any indication from France if it intends to continue testing nuclear devices at its sites in the Pacific.
(3) Has France given any undertaking regarding disposal of nuclear waste from its numerous previous tests and its recent tests in the Pacific.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is particularly disappointing that France continues its nuclear tests program in spite of the well known opposition of South Pacific states. As a matter of principle, Australia condemns each test that takes place in French Polynesia and has made its opposition known at the highest levels. More recently, I had the opportunity to reaffirm our strong opposition to French nuclear testing with the French Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Mr Alain Vivien, during his recent visit to Canberra. The Government also avails itself of other opportunities, such as at the United Nations and other international forums, to draw attention to the opposition in our region to such tests.

Australia is also working to achieve the early conclusion of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban (CTBT) which would end all nuclear tests by all countries, in all environments, for all time. To this end, we will again co-sponsor a resolution with New Zealand at the United Nations General Assembly in October. A CTBT will be an important step towards ending and reversing the nuclear arms race and discouraging potential new weapons states.
(2) France has conducted six nuclear tests this year; no further tests are expected in 1991.

The number of French nuclear tests annually has declined in recent years. However, the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, has stated that France does not intend to cease testing because it considers such tests essential to the modernisation of its nuclear weapons. France has adopted a more transparent attitude to its nuclear testing practices and Australia acknowledges this gesture.

(3) French officials have previously reported on their procedures for cleaning up, recovering and disposing of nuclear wastes resulting from French weapons testing in the Pacific. These procedures involve deep burial on Mururoa Atoll and were described in the report of the joint New Zealand,
Australian and Papua New Guinea Scientific Mission to Mururoa Atoll in 1983.

France has ratified the South Pacific Environmental Program (SPREP) Convention which requires participating parties to prevent, reduce and control pollution of the Convention Area and to ensure sound environmental management and development of natural resources and the protection of the endangered flora and fauna. SPREP also requires Parties to the Convention and major extra- regional powers to prohibit the dumping and disposal of radioactive wastes and radioactive matter in the Convention area. However, France has declared that in so far as it is concerned, the prescriptions of the Convention will not cover wastes and other matter entailing a level of pollution caused by radioactivity to a degree less than that prescribed by the recommendations of the International Atomic Energy Agency.
